Monte Forte is very close to Ruins of St. Paul’s. I traveled here after visiting Ruins of St. Paul’s. It is said that Monte Forte was for military defense in previous. You can see many forts there. It was very interesting for me. You can see many real cannons. I took many
We walked up.. take the escalator if you don't want to walk. Escalator is for the museum, you can access to the Fort from the museum. Seniors should take the escalator.
Nothing much other than the view... Locals visit to practice exercise... Best picture taken was with the Virgin Mary statue...

If you like uphill walks and scenery, you will like this place. You can get an all around view of Macau. You also get to know a little bit more of the history of Macau and about typhoons too. This is also where the Macau museum is. Lots of canons on display and it's actually a
Entry is free. Be cautious climbing the stairs up. The museum is here, but not much else in the way of the history of the Fort. Offers great views all around the city so great place for photos.
Great views of Macau from the hilltop. A natural continuation of a visit to a Macau museum. Cannons are very impressive for kids.

Well worth having a good look at this. Take a few hours. the steps up to the main gate of the fort though are steep and narrow. Probably not good for small children or prams or older people or people with walking sticks. There is road/car/taxi access up the back of the fort

The site is quite close to the Ruins of St. Paul's however involves a fair few steep steps to get to from the Ruins. The Museum of Macau is at the top and the gardens around the Forte are quite pleasant affording great 360 degree views of old Macau. I found taking some of the

One of the first things that were built in Macau for defensive purposes was this fort. It's right by the St.Paul's ruins and formed a missionary, military and educational complex along with the St.Paul's college (which is destroyed by fire). Don't be lazy and climb up there.
Take the short hike up the hill. You will be rewarded with Museum of Macau and great views of the city and mainland China from up there. The Museum is close on Mondays.
From the Ruins of St Paul's, this is very close. It is a gentle stroll to the top of the fortress, and you are afforded with fantastic views from all parts of Macau.

Climb up to the top of the fort and you will not be disappointed. 360 degree views out over Macau, with amazing views of the bay, the historic centre and the casinos. Free to enter (although there is a museum which has an entry fee) and lots of photo opportunities. Well worth

The fort is right next to the ruins and is very picturesque due to its stone construction and greenery. You need to walk some steps up to reach the actual fort and museum. So it is not ideal if you need to take a baby stroller with you. You can see great views of the city
Monte forte lies on right side of Ruins of St paul.. hardly few mt aways.. so don't skip , if you are there... On a bright sunny day, you will get 360 view of macau peninsula

There are 2 ways of getting to the top of the fort - by climbing the usual stone stairs, or by accessing it via escalators through the museum. Canons are plentiful at the top. The best attraction is the view as one has a bird's eye view of Macau city. Plenty of photo
Very close to St. Paul ruins you can climb up to the fortress to see all Macau and take great photos up there.
After visiting the Ruins of St Paul's, grab the stairs leading to the forte on the right. At the top you a great view of the city and of the Ruins with less people in front! ;)

from atop the old fort walls. Check out the canons & the stone construction. Then, wander down to the Macau Museum. The ruins of St. Paul, the fort walls and the museum are all "part of a whole" in terms of the history of Macau.

It is on the Heritage Trail next to Ruins of St. Paul. Climb the stairs up to the fort for some great views of the city. There is the Macao Museum at the top, which is worth a view. The fort is free, and museum is free only on Wednesday. Do this for the views.

The fort has an awesome view from the top and is a great piece of Portuguese heritage. It is well worth the walk and you can see a number of historical artifacts. I don't know what people about the escalators as I could find none.

Walk or take 3 escalators to the top of the fortress where you will find a museum. See the museum for a charge and/or go look around the observation area for a great view of the city, harbor, and China as well as of the cannons.

Once you walk through the historic area from the square you arrive at the ruins of St. Paul. To your right is fortress. It is worth the short climb of stairs to get to the top. You have views from all sides. You can see mainland China as well as some gaudy casino buildings.
The place offers a breath of fresh air, beautiful scenic views of nature as well as the city's view. This is a must visit place once in Macau.
It's worth a visit to the top of the fortress which is FOC, lovely views of the city. We chanced upon it when we were looking for washroom after our visit to the Ruins of St Paul.
In reality Monte Forte is not much and you would probably only visit it because you are visiting the Ruins of St Paul which is not far away.

If you start in Senando square, then walk over to St. Paul's, the fort is just above - keep climbing up the hill to the right. As fort's go it's not out of this world (though it is well maintained), but it has a great view of the islands for sunset and it is quite picturesque.
This was a bonus when visiting Old Macau or the St. Pauls Ruins as it is very close. A large fort with dozens of old original cannons and a view of the city.

With some interesting exhibits, you can reach the top of the fortress by a series of escalators, which, on a hot day, is a good thing. The views from the top were nice, but equally nice was the fact that the top of the fortress was a peaceful place to look out and relax. The

This small museum depicts the history of Macau. It is very well made, and maintained. It's certainly worth the price of admission. Featuring artefacts from Macau's colonization period, where the church had a strong influence.
Canons are placed at vantage points; a great view of the whole city and the port. A small museum atop. Nice place to take photos.

Macau fortress is just next to the ruins of St. Cathedral in the main Macau island. The fort area i swell maintained with stoned pathways. You will see a lot of locals jogging here during the evenings and many carrying their pets for a stroll. The fortress has a big garden area
the fort is located on the top of a hill and offers viewers a great look at Macao and the neighboring Chinese town

This place is locate across from Ruins of St Paul's, good work out to climb up all the steep steps to view the fort, great city view up there, cannot believe this place was built since 1617 still maintain a good shape.

No doubt it is a nice fort, well preserved. However, having been to Jodhpur Fort in India, this one could be called as tiny. The canyons were also almost half the size as compared to the Jodhpur ones. If you liked this one, then you will go crazyy covering the entire Jodhpur

This was pretty cool to go visit. On a big hill not surprisingly and was a hot day. Lots of work going on at the front of the fort but inside it was great to see and on the roof it was an opportunity for great photos.
This is one of the greatest sites I have visited. The old cannons, the steep stairs, Definitely a place I would go to again!
The place is nice and you get to see a real piece from Macau history. The best thing about it is the great view you have. On a good day you can see all Macau and even China

Amazing how well preserved the fort is considering it was built in the early 1600's. Be brave, and walk up the 52 m to the main gate ... the steps are narrow, and uneven, but even they have lasted well. Inside, you have an fantastic view of the region. The fort overlooks the

Not to far up the hill from the ruins of St. Paul's Cathedral, a set of steep stairs ascends to the interior of the old Portuguese fort. If you don't have your comfy hiking shoes on, find the back way into the Forte. Its there, cleverly hidden, a bit to the left of the stairs.

Walked up from Ruins of St. Paul. Can be a good exercise walking up to the top, remember to wear comfortable shoes. Once at the top, you are exposed to an amazing view of Macau, get your cameras ready. You can view the Grand Lisboa Hotel from here. Walked one round and you will

Located in the historic precinct near the ruins of St.Pauls. Can enter via the museum or walk around the wall and up the stone stairs. Outstanding 360 degrees of Macau from the top of the forte. Free entry.

Many people are unaware that the way to get here is just beside the ruins of St. Paul. Just a tip, you have to wear a comfortable slipper or shoes because the stairway is stiff. When you arrive at the top of the hill, you will be amazed of the view. You will see the sofitel,

If you want, you can skip the museum and access the top of the fort for free using escalators, getting great views in all directions. The cannon pointed directly at the Grand Lisboa would be fun to see in use.
Right next to the ruins of St. Paul's (behind to the right) this has great views of the city and is well maintained. Worth popping in.

When facing the stairs leading up to the Macau Museum, you can turn right and follow the signs to the gate entrance to the fort and simply skip the museum. The path leads up to the top of the fort where there are plenty of opportunities to take pictures of Macau and its skyline.

This is just a short walk from Senado Square, the Fort offers a great view of the city given its location on top of a hill. The fortress has solid high walls and cannons strategically located around its perimeter. The fort also houses the Macau Museum. If you go up early in the

One of the key attractions in Macao, so if you have the time you should plan in at least an hour for a quick walkaround. I was there on a weekday and there is not much tourist, compared to the Ma Temple.

There are lots of well maintained walkways and STAIRS on this hill to access the fort. Tourists and locals visit this hill since it had great views and is cooler than below. Lots of people walk their dogs here. Go to the top of the fort. The views are best from here. There are

It was incredibly hot the day I did this, but it was definitely worth it. I went through the park to the right of the Ruins of St Paul's and up the stairs under the beautiful trees. For someone who has an average level of fitness, even in the really hot weather, this wasn't
within old historic town, take the time to stroll around and enjoy the views on the city to have 360 degrees view

It was hard to find and straight up an uneven unmarked walkway on a very hot and humid day. The gardens were beautiful and the fountains were nice. The entire area as well as the views were worth seeing. Bring your camera.
- first time visit - accessible from the Macau Museum (with air-con) - able to see the whole Macau and a part of Mainland ps. weather was too hot that i stayed only 15 mins there
I went with my family. Great view of Macao but need a bit of climbing. There is a Macao museum at the place itself. Great experience.

Not everything has to be casinos and lights in Macau right? The fort is just a short walk from the old church front, there are some nice views of the Lisboa (if it's not too cloudy like in my case). When I went there I wanted to go to the museum but I was very short on time to

Built by the Jesuits as there head quarters the Mount fortress provided an excellent defence against the Dutch in 1622. Easy to get around has lift and elevators, worth a visit has an excellent museum and views over Macau and mainland china.

Great views once you get to the top and to see the cannons . You can go by stairs or the escalator by the St. Paul's cathedral there is a cafe up the top to get a drink . We went up the stairs and down the escalator
Take the escalator and save your energy. This is nice walkable fort that affords a panoramic view of the city, from impressive hotels to multi-coloured dwellings crowded together.

I was not prepared to see such a huge fort and to have to climb a few steep flights of steps, passing by a statue of Matteo Ricci along the way to reach it. Having been to Malacca recently, I had expected to see a small square structure with a few cannons pointing in this or

In English, Fortress of Our Lady of the Mount of St. Paul. It was built after the completion of the Cathedral of St. Paul to protect the properties of the Jesuits in Macau. On the other hand, the Museum of Macau was built on top of the fort in 1990s to house Macau's historical
Worth a visit and walk up the many stairs. Great views over the city from several angles.Main museum underneath but costs to enter. Display of the diggings free entry and a cool spot on a hot day.
It was great to visit this historic place , and if you are portuguese you will enjoy it even more!! Beautiful scenery & place to take nice photos!

Another very classical example of Spanish / Portuguese Fortified post; to guard Macau's coastal lines and shores. Replica cannons will give you a hint of what may happened several hundred years ago. Not to miss!

It's a bit of a hike up some stairs from Saint' Paul's ruins to the top of the hill where the fort was. You get a great view of the bay, and a good sense of history. Doesn't take long, highly recommend it.

If you visit the Ruins of St. Paul, this Forte is next to it. The most interesting view is that one can view Casino Grand Lisboa far away. The outside shape of the Casino is like a cannon ball is exploded.
Wish that they had a book to show the very interesting corridor displaying differences in discoveries in Eastern and Western World. Fantastic view of Macau from roof.

One of the two main forts that protected the city of Macau during the days of the Portuguese and the British management, this is located right next to (and above) the Ruins of St Paul's Church. Unless you're in Macau only to gamble at the casinos, you're definitely going to St

Set a top a hill near the centre of Macau Island this fortress complete with cannons offers views of the city and down towards the ruins of St Pauls Cathedral. There is a small museum at the centre. There is not a lot to do there except enjoy the views and keep out of the way of

We enjoyed the short walk up to the fort, and the views were amazing - and available from so many angles! Its worth noting that none of the cannons point to mainland China, and then that gives you an idea of which direction you are looking...

we went to the fort through the museum and were spared the trek up. the expanse contains cannons of various sizes and landscaping. the view of the city is quite incredible from here, though it needs to be a day without haze. the periphery is earmarked with a yellow line and
I enjoyed the trek to the fort. Go during a time when it is not sunny. You can get amazing view of the city from here.

The climb to get to the top is so worth it - past all the bird cages hanging from trees to the cobblestoned pathways. The kids were fascinated with the cannons and the grown ups loved the view - you can see the old and the new all from one spot. Peaceful and contemplative in

Make sure you climb the steps and check out the cannons and the magnificent view of the city. On one side you can see the residential buildings, on another the sea, and on another the casinos. Definitely worth a visit!
A good place to visit for spectacular panoramic views of the city. The fort walls and canons are interesting too.

Very close to the more popular Ruins of St. Paul, this place was a military fortress. You could reach the top via two ways I think. Via the Macau Museum escalators or via the stairs in front of the fort. I suggest you to take the stairs for the view. Up top you could enjoy the

This place was in walking distance from the ruins of St. Paul's Cathedral. My family and I walked up the stairs to reach the top of the fortress even though they were tired. You can reach the top by taking the escalator up to the Museum instead if you don't fancy walking up the

Macau is not all about casinos and high-class 'walkers'. Fortaleza de Monte is a living testimony to the historic past of Macau under the Portuguese rule. Built in 1617-1626 to protect the St. Paul’s Church property, it later became a military fortress for the defence of Macau.

Fortaleza do Monte is the historical military centre of the former Portuguese colony of Macau. Originally built in the 17th century to protect the Jesuits. The view of the city is great and the history behind it sheds light into the fascinating history of Macau.
Great view of the city below and indeed of the lighthouse above. Worth a meander around the grounds too.
We loved it here. After the cathedral this was a great change of pace. The views were brilliant and if you can avoid the tours then the photo opportunities are awesome. Do it, it doesn't disappoint.

From here you can see the ruins if St Pauls Cathedral. You also have a good view over Macau. The is a shop were you can drink something or have something to eat. There are canons everything looks very good.

Monte Forte is also known as Fortaleza do Monte in Portuguese. The fort was initially built in 1617-1626 by St. Paul’s Church to protect their property. Later on it became a military fortress for the defence of Macau. One website has the fort perimeter at over 330 feet

The Museum at Fortaleza do Monte is worth the visit, but the best part is upstairs. Take some time to enjoy the sunset from the the top of the Fortress - one of the best views of the city. Very touristy and super-crowded area in the surroundings, be patient.

Go the Historic Centre and follow the road (all uphill) to St. Paul's, turn right and head up the stairs. Warning: although not a strenuous climb by any means, in the summer heat and humidity it can be a bit of work. Luckily most of it is shaded. Once you are at the top you

Walked up to this place not really knowing where we where gouing or what to expect. Getting to the top in my opinion was not difficult but then again not that easy ! getting to te top and walking around was ok but left a little dissapointed as ther did not seem to be much

It's easy to get to Monte Forte; it's directly to your right if you are facing St. Paul's ruins.The fortress is nestled atop a hill, hence, the challenging climb. The pavement is also a bit uneven so one has to be very careful when walking. We took the stairs to get to the top

Easily accessible from the St. Paul's ruins, the fort offers great views over Macau and to the Chinese mainland. Historically significant the fort still has many canons in place and some nice gardens. For those who can't make the hike up the hill you can take an escalator from
Centrally located fort has good views across Macau. There's plenty of photo opportunities. It's worth the walk up the stairs to get there.

We popped in after seeing St Paul's ruins as they are very close. There are a lot of stairs that seem to go on for a long time but there is a small shop where you can buy drinks really cheap close to the top; it was a relief it in the humidity and hot sun! At the top of the

This fortress is located in the historical center of Macau, next to the remains of St. Paul's. The site of the Macau Museum is also in the fortress, but you don't have to visit the museum to enjoy the fort. Go up from St. Paul's (it takes a bit of time) and you will reach the
Loved getting to see this historical place and how the locals interact with it today. I especially liked that I went near sunset and could see the city light up.
Monte Forte is the historical military centre of the former Portuguese colony of Macau, in the People's Republic of China. You should enjoin it

You're right next to the St Paul's ruins anyway, so combine the 2 attractions. Easy climb to the top, free entrance, and great views of the cityscape, and some different, photogenic, views of the St Paul's ruin on the way up - and from the top. Definitely worth visiting.
Great views looking over Macau as you walk around the grounds. So make sure you have your camera. A little cafe there too for coffee etc.

A short walk from Ruins of St. Paul's to the base of this Fortress. Required lots of stamina to climb the stairs to the top. Worth the effort. By looking at the placement of the cannons, we were transported back in time when Macau was just an enclave surrounded by the sea and

I visited on the 14/04/2014 and I'm glad I went. It's only about a ten minute walk from the busy areas of the town centre. It is however a very steep walk to get up to it. It offers amazing views and it was not to busy with tourists.

Once you get over the height and the cannons, the fort isn't all that impressive. I left there with 2 big questions... What are these cannons aimed at exactly? and How exactly was this designed to protect them from the Jesuits? The walk to the fort can be rough for some but

It is a small fort which can be accessed through the stairs beside the ruins of St. Paul or upon exit of the Museum of Macau. The fort is very much similar to that of the Walled City of Intramuros in Manila. The walls are thick and made of adobe. At the time we visited there

The place gives you good views of Macau (smog permitting) and you can even glimpse over to mainland China. Can even get a good from above view of the cathedral ruins. While there are some historic things to see of the fort, the place acts more like a park for the locals. Go

C1 ( 2013.06.19 ) I didn't know easy way, so I went up round forte. At that time, weather temperature was over 35 degrees. I was tired in the heat. Anyway forte was not charming but cityview of Macau was very good. and there was a small museum where has some exhibitions. There

I missed this on a previous visit to Macau . For us , it was worth it just for the view . You get a different view of the Ruins of St Paul , looking down and from the side . Macau is an interesting place to walk around and the fort gives a good perspective of the layout of the

Across from the remnants of St Pauls Cathedral, the old city fortress is located up a series of steep steps, and has relics from it's past including, canons and the Macau museum( closed mondays). It offers great vistas of the surrounding area and wonderful scenic photo

This beautiful Portuguese fortress I visited it during my tour in the historic center of Macau, very easy to reach being located at the top of a hill just a few meters from the ruins of St. Paul's to reach the top there are two ways or use the simple and convenient staircases

Nice views of Macau but like anything else not related to gambling in Macau it was a little underwhelming. More information on the history of the fort, better accessibility and better maintenance would make this a much better tourist destination.

right beside the St. Paul facade ruins, this fort contains a cafe, bathrooms, the Macau museum and several cannons lining the top. From the top you can see most of the city. There are some interesting trees and a few benches to sit and watch the world go by. Free.

It's just a minute or two walk away from St. Paul's Cathedral. It's a short walk up the stairs (or take the elevator). Old bricks and beautiful plants blends together. When you're at the top, take a good look at the view of Macau, which is houses with Lisboa at the back.

A very good view of the city and a great place to take photos. One of UNESCO World Heritage designations and it's right next to the museum. A lot quieter than the Ruins of St. Paul. A little climbing required to get up to the fort.

The Monte Forte attraction, which is a member of the UNESCO World Heritage designation for the Historic Centre of Macau is located right next to the famous Ruins of St. Paul. It is a nice place to visit but needs to be combined with the Macau Museum, within the same grounds to
ohh this is a wonderful spot to come and see all the old and new buildings in macau and its worth a trip to the top to see the old fort that protected the portgueses people before any other rulers
not much to see beyond a few cannons, gardens. The all round view of Macau is impressive and worth a climb to the top if only to go to the museum.

The fort was built between 1617 and 1626 by Jesuits. Nice views over Macau (when it is not hazy). The cannons were only used once: the only feat of arms is the aborted invasion of the Dutch in 1622. More interesting is the in housed Macau Museum (see seperate review).

Our taxi driver dropped us off at the bottom of the hill and told us to walk up to the fortress. Once we got up there, the scene is very nice. We have a panoramic view the town from high up. Along the fortress walls, there are cannons from the past. Trees in the garden are
If you want to see Macau, hike up a bit to the Monte Forte. Stunning view of Macau from the top. The steps can be a bit steep if you're going up from Ruins of St Paul's.
A really nice view of the surroundings is available Many people were there and, with the size, you just wait for minutes and you have a chance to see what you wanted. Take pictures.
We ventured up to the Fort after visiting the St. Paul ruins. We had a good view of the city; the new immersed with the historic. It was a relaxing break to sit above the city life.

There is a bit of an uphill walk involved in getting to the fort, but once there one has a 360 degree view of the city and into mainland China. I didn't try out the museum, but just seeing the large defensive structure up close was enough for me.

Free access to this historic and important landmark, built as a statement in stone of the Portuguese strength and intent to colonise in 1622. It is well worth the climb up to the top to see the views from the Fort Walls over the Pearl river delta to Mainland China. The

We were blessed with very clear day in Macau last week so we opted for a trip up the fort, near St. Pauls. This traditional European style fort is nothing particularly special if you've seen the hundreds of similar versions spread across Europe, but its not bad. You can take
google: One of the best place to get sunset with city view in Macao! Take times in the National Museum in the afternoon, then walking around Monte Fort park is truly relaxing to call your day trip here.
Historical fort. Properly preserve according to the age. A 360 degrees lookout in the middle of Macau side. Small hops with souvenirs a and clean WC service.
Lots of steep walking to get to the top, difficult on a hot day! Great 360 views with a museum at the top. Plenty of history here.

text.quote: Sophisticated museum opened in 1998, featuring historical & cultural exhibits on Macau's past.
trip: The Macau Museum is a well appointed exhibit of local history through text, audio and video grams, actual physical displays of scaled boats, an old printing press, old carts; even several constructions with local people involved in former activities such as a few friends playing
This museum, besides being situated on a beautiful viewpoint, is interested and worth a trip if you want to see how the life in the old Portuguese enclave of Macau was. I enjoyed the history.

Just up the hill overlooking the Ruins of St. Paul's, the Macao Museum is definitely worth an hour or two of your time to get an understanding of Macao's history! And the entry fee is less than U.S. $2.00 per person--cheaper if you're over 65😃!

After a long ferry ride we got to Macau.Hot weather so we went into the delightful air conditioned museum.We learnt a lot and spent more time here than we thought we would.Shame it's not nearer Hong Kong but otherwise would go again
I had nothing to do so decided to check this place out. It was a good museum with a few attractions. I found my visit educational also

This is one of the best museums I’ve visited in Asia. Combining the history of Europe with China it brings together how both cultures interacted with each other from the 16th century. There’s lots of interactive displays and for me it provides a new sense of the importance of

This was an interesting little museum in the old town of Macau. It’s cheap to get in and it’s worth a look, but it’s not a must do by any measure. It kind of gives you an overview of Macau history including contemporary history. And they have a re-creation of a typical Macau
They do not accept credit cards and they do not have change. At least that what they told me when I gave them Visa and then $100 bill in Hong Kong funds. Weird.
It is a good place for tourists to know more traditional macau lifestyle. Price for adult is mop 15 now.

This was a wonderful addition to our day in Macau. There was lots of information to read on the various displays throughout the museum about much of the interesting Portuguese and Asian history over the centuries. I wish I had had more time to spend to take it all in.

Beautifully set out with some very good exhibits and well explained. Unfortunately the 3rd floor was closed to the public on the day we visited which was a shame.

I actually enjoyed my visit here, made better because it was free admission the day we went. I think the best thing is that they managed to build this into the the existing fort infrastructure, very clever.
Excellent exhibits and beautifully displayed. This museum was just the right size and gave a really good overview of Macau.

People tend to overlook this tiny, yet gorgeous and well maintained historical Museum on top of the Mount Fortress and Old City Walls (Fortaleza do Monte). They have managed to blend both Chinese and Portuguese historical events and way of living along the centuries. A must

A well kept and interactive musium giving clear history of Macau. Sited on the Mount Fotress and Old City Walls present the relevance and connectivity to the historic Macau. A good visit and well informed of historic Macau after the visit.
This was a very interesting exhibition housed in the Palacio de Canton, itself a beautiful building to visit on its own. Staff was attentive and helpful when appropriate without hovering.

This small museum, built below the fortress, is Macau's major history museum. The exhibition is a bit underwhelming. The whole place is overcrowded with people screaming and kids running around. Our overall experience is far from ideal.

Free for child below 12. Cheap tickets for adults.. If you can explain what the antiques, old machinery, and stuffs. Kids love this place as they can understand how their chinese/portugese grandparents live their lives.. Links to the fort, cannon tower.. Good site. +++++1
Macanese = Chinese + Purtugese is good to learn very well layouted and well preserved artifacts wont take more than 45 mins to cover
Unfortunately we got here too early and were disappointed that we could not see the museum. It is open from 10 am - 5.30 pm everyday except Monday, when it is closed.

After wandering around the ruins and the fort, I decided to see how much the museum cost. It was only 15MOP so I popped in. They have many interactive displays and models set up. It was an enjoyable 30min and I probably could have stayed longer if I hadn’t been hungry.

Yesssss, I didn't want, because it was sunny, but my 5yo insisted and I have to admit it was the one of the best places we've seen in Macau. Gorgeous museum, colorful, very nicely arranged, creative, informative, funny. The first time in my life I got detailed explanation of
I went there 2 years ago and it was very nice as it displayed all the historic culture of Macau from when I was a child....

Adjacent to ruins of St Paul's. One of the few attractions where entrance fee was charged but again was very reasonable. Nice look into the history of Macau. Also going through the museum to the top of the fort, saves the climb by foot. The view from the fort top is stunning.

Good place to be with interesting facts and artifacts about the history of Macau. The place is well organize with lots of information. However, a casual stroll around the museum just looking at the display is equally interesting. My 20yr old and 11yr old both enjoyed it. The

A small museum close to the Ruins. Cash only. Receptionist charged my young kids adult tickets because they didn't have student IDs on them. View of the city on the fort was nice. Skip this if you have kids. They couldn't wait to get out of there.
Must see the 新娘轿 (bride carriage) its so so beautiful. 200% recommend. There is a session of street seller call for business, interesting.

Small, but comprehensive museum; gives a good overview of Macau's history. Start with the museum, then work your way down the hill to experience old town Macau. A refreshing counter-point to the over-the-top glitz of Cotai Strip.
The museum have lot of model to show you the past of Macau ,won't make you boring at the top of the building,you can see the cannon and the view of Macau,
A good museum with lots of thing to look at some good interactive and a good childrens area... enjoyed looking at the old pupets and making of fire works
Nice location near St. Paul ruins, a lot of stuff inside museum with English description and English voice.

The Macao Museum merits an hour or so of tourists time.... it is not big but well explains the history of Macau, its people and its culture. You will get a glimpse of the old Macau, the old Macau unspoilt by casinos and high end residential developments for mainlanders. There

This is a good, smallish museum which explains the history of Macau, it's people and cultures. The street of Macau houses was particularly interesting.

Very well put together museum. Next to the Fort. Nice big exhibits. You learn a lot about Macao history and culture after the visit. We were there on a Tuesday and it was free. Definitely worth a visit!

You have to pay a fee to enter this museum. It was quite interesting to learn about the history of Macao and western and Chinese cultures blended on this island.

This museum is a gem full of items that relate to the history of Macao. I enjoyed touring the 3 levels, there are escalators and elevators if you have some problems walking up stairs. At the top is a great view of the city of Macao with parts of the old wall.

The museum was very interesting and teaches you about the architecture and the history of Macau. What stood out was the different types of houses and the history of the Cantonese opera. Personally I enjoyed the other sites more as they were in the open air, but the museum serves

It's an affordable and nice place to visit. Costs $15 MOP per person, if I'm not mistaken. There are some exhibits about the history of macao, mostly Chinese. It's not a big museum and the third floor was under renovation when we were there. The entire visit took about an hour
Very cheap entry, only £1.50, when we visited. Enough to keep you interested and out of the heat for about an hour.

This is one of the best things to do in Macau. You enter near the Ruins of St. Paul, and it works its way up through several floors to a garden that is also part of the Guia Fortress, which is on the other side. The gift shop has a large selection of Macau stamps, which was a

... and you should see this. It is very interesting to have a look on these historic objets, styles and design. It is a good and introducing overview on the history of Macao. There is a children's place in the upper level if needed ;-)

This is a great little museum, plenty of exhibits from past Macau. Well displayed and set out showing typical home interiors from olden Macau life both Chinese & Portugese homes. Some beautiful religious icons too.
This museum is just behind the ruins of St.Paul's and is well worth a look. It is cheap and will occupy an interesting hour. Look out for the dog on the end of the canon!

The exhibits in the museum range in quality and interest, but there's a lot to take away from the descriptions for the exhibits. For those who have limited knowledge of Macau, this offers a great opportunity to better understand how Macau sat at the intersection of West and East

You need to walk-up to the hill of the "Fortaleza do Monte" (don't worry it is not exhausted). The museum presents the history of the city and territory of the former Portuguese colony of Macau. I was missing links to the history of Hong Kong as both were leased from China. On
A most magnificent museum could have spent all day there . Beautiful displays with explanations in English has air con & seating outside when finished your tour

It's a very well-designed small museum, inserted into the centre of the fortress that dominated Macau for four hundred years, until the casinos took over. It offers some fine insights into that complicated colonial history of oppression and cultural compromise. The fortress
This museum atop the fortress hill presents Macau history, with emphasis on the Portuguese contribution and the Macanese culture, on a inviting, multimedia way.

It looked liked a great museum. Free on Sunday, I went there and it was interesting to see the history of Macau. Great descriptions and displays. However, more than an hour is recommended for this as there is so much to look at.

For about an hour I wandered around the Macau Museum. It was a fascinating tour around the cultural history of the city and the mix of European and Chinese cultures that have created Macau. The exhibits range from art, statues, scale models, film clips, things for the children
average not much to see, was close to st pauls ruins. there is a good view up the top to see the grand lisboa hotel.
We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this interesting and well displayed little museum which gives a good overview of Macau's past and a welcome break from the steam heat.

It is located at the top of the hill near the ruins of St Paul. From that side there are mechanical escalators, from the other side of the hill its a steep climb through streets and stairs. It has a small section on ancient history but most of the content is Macau around 100

Having visited St. Pal's on a previous day, I made my way back here just to see the museum. It was worth it. The story is neatly told in a succession of dioramas and reconstructed scenes. There is exciting stuff and interesting stuff as well. The atmosphere is cool and
Had no expectations going in but enjoyed this museum. Well presented and a nice walk thru Macau history without being dull. Great views of the city from the top.

Fantastic place to learn about the interesting history of Macau. The Portuguese influence, blended with Chinese culture around the nearby streets gives the place a really unique feel and charm. Unfortunately I couldn't find much of an explanation regarding why Macau is now

The museum does not deserve a special visit, it is small and there is nothing interesting about it. On the other hand, it is located on the top of a hill with an excellent view of the entire historical part of Macau. Here is also a historic fortress.

Good small museum located on Mount hill where the fortress was built by the Jesuits in the 1600s. Costs 15MD (about $2US) to enter. Has large children's section where they can learn all about cannon ball making.

There is more regional history but the portugal influence is palpable. Only cost $2 to get in and they have a nice escalator that takes you up to the museum and then deposits you out at the top of the fort. Nice little bit of history and some interactive exhibits many in

Located right next to the St Paul Ruins is the Macau History Museum. If you really want to get a full understanding of Macau, then make sure to make time for the Macau History Museum. The Macau History Museum is built inside an old fort. The price to get into the museum is less

The Macao Museum is close to the ruins of St Paul. They have exhibitions of how Macau was founded by the Portuguese, and expanded under both Portuguese and Chinese influences. It's a worth while visit if you have time or if you want to learn about the history of Macau.
Small museum, but full of history and old artifacts. Fun to see and learn about Macao. Probably not exciting for younger children.
One of the few places actually worth seeing in Macau. We got lucky and it was free entry when we went (Monday and public holiday). Quite small but some interesting exhibits about Macau

Located inside Monte fort. Avg. collection of Chinese culture and heritage items. A lot smaller as compared to other museums in China, but Macau in general is a small place. You can browse through the displays fairly quickly and the souvenir shop is a bit of disappointment.
Very good location small museum, opposite maa temple historical place old ask guide Macau history must visit

Compared to the museums in hongkong this was small, uninformative and boring. Waste of time and money. Also the signage was bad. We took a long and sweaty walk around the hill to the top as we were following the sign for the fort. However it was just on top of the museum by

Siting inside the Monte fortress, this fairly recent museum convincingly conveys he fusion of Portuguese and Chinese histories and cultures that met in Macau. It has exhibits of archaeological objects as well as historic things. Good for kids too.

From the Ruins, you can walk/trek up Fortress Hill to the museum. It's a challenge going uphill in the summer but in the cooler months, the trek would be much more enjoyable. The artifacts and exhibits are well-curated. There's also a cafe inside which serves some traditional
This is a good chance to view the life of the ordinary people in the last centuries. Very interesting place.

Macau's history is interesting. The museum was well presented. Entrance fee is cheap. The museum has nice displays. It's very accessible as it's just beside Ruins of St Paul. They have escalators going to the main museum. I'm not sure if this place is handicapped friendly as I
Do not miss this wonderful free museum in the center of Macau. Well worth a visit. Allow 1 hour to take in all the exhibits. Take time to walk around Historic area.

Easiest way up to it and it and the Fort above it is by proceeding to the right track when facing from the Ruins of St Paul, theres a series of escalators that will get you right up into the museum, at the end 3rd floor of the museum you can proceed to the top of the fort

I'm not really a museum person just being honest. I think overall it's a good museum has some great views of city outside w/ the fort & cannons. So I didn't really spend much time in the museum I enjoyed outside views much more..

A nice small museum. Small fee to get in. We didn't plan on coming here but as we had walked to the Ruins of St Pauls it was just across the road so we saw the opportunity to visit. Beautiful ancient artefacts as you'd expect from a museum. A lot showcase Asias history which
if you want to know the history of Macau this is a place to go a interactive Museum under the colonial fortress at the top you can visit the fortress and have a general view of Macau

Definitely worth checking out, head up to the top and enjoy the view over the bay. You can get photos with the canons or explore the lovely gardens. Lots of grassy areas to sit and enjoy the sunlight.

Easy to find, and cheap entry, even free to Seniors. Very well laid out, with plenty of modern exhibits and some excellent models. Perfectly sized for one visit - of 1 to 2 hours. The museum is easy to walk around, with plenty of signs and information. A greeat place to visit
Everything in one place-all detalistów about history and chinese culture.and amazing view from top-no need to pay for a view.ticket 15MOP. Worth.

Adjacent to the Ruins of St Paul. The Macau Museum is a comprehensive exhibits of the culture, lifestyle, practices and customs. Must not give this a miss. We were there on 2 Jan and admission was free!

We had a good hour here, no need to have a formalised tour, as the museum is easy to walk around, with plenty of signage everywhere, so easy to find your way around, and easy to get a taste of the history, without information overload. Really well laid out - staff friendly too.

again a must visit during your short trip. shows the character of this city. gives the old British charm with the history to reckon
Nice place for a visit. Again if you are not into museums then this wouldn't be the place for you. Very well set out and informative. Great old artifacts. Covers Portuguese and Chinese history :)
A definite must when visiting Macau. A very interesting insight into Macau history and culture. Make sure you leave time to explore the roof garden.
Very nice museum giving you an idea of Macau. Favorite rooom is on 2nd floor where they have all the main Macanese dishes displayed.
Around 1 hour to complete, it's a rather small museum in one of the cultural sites alley, right across an authentic rustic old temple. Very informative about the history of Macau

text.wiki:
The Macau Fisherman's Wharf (Chinese: 澳門漁人碼頭; Portuguese: Doca dos Pescadores) is an integrated waterfront, hotel, convention, dining, retail and entertainment complex in Sé, Macau, China.


== History ==
The construction of the theme park took 5 years, before an opening ceremony by the Chief Executive of Macau and trial operation began on December 31, 2005. After one year of trial operation, the wharf was officially opened on 31 December 2006.


== Architecture ==
The complex includes over 70 stores and restaurants in buildings built in the style of different world seaports such as Cape Town, and Amsterdam, a convention and exhibition centre, a marina, two hotels and a casino spanning over 133,000 m2 of area. The theme park gets 40% of its area from reclamation from the sea.


== Visitor attractions ==
East meets west attractions include:
Rocks Hotel, modeled on the elaborate charms of 18th century Victoriana, providing 72 guestrooms and suites.
Harbourview Hotel, based on 18th century Prague design, provides 389 comfortable guest rooms and 55 spacious suites.
Roman Amphitheatre, an outdoor Colosseum equipped with 2,000 seats, designed as a venue for concerts and other performances .
Convention and Exhibition Centre, one of the largest venues for meetings and banquets in the city centre .
Legend Boulevard, a complex of retail, hotels, dining and a casino themed on coastal towns including Miami, Cape Town, New Orleans, Amsterdam, Spain, Lisbon, Rome and English, the Palace and the Italian Riviera. There are different cuisines from all over the world such as Jade Orchid, Vic's, Praha Restaurant, etc..Babylon Casino, features VIP room and mass gaming floor, and near the slots casino which is connected by a skybridge in Harbourview Hotel.


== See also ==
List of Macao-related topics
Fisherman's Wharves in other places


== References ==

text.wiki:
The Venetian Macao (Chinese: 澳門威尼斯人) is a luxury hotel and casino resort in Macau owned by the American Las Vegas Sands company. The Venetian is a 39-story, casino hotel on the Cotai Strip in Macau. The 10,500,000-square-foot (980,000 m2) Venetian Macao is modeled on its sister casino resort The Venetian Las Vegas. The Venetian Macao is the 2nd largest casino in the world, the largest single structure hotel building in Asia, and also the seventh-largest building in the world by floor area.
The main hotel tower was finished in July 2007 and the resort officially opened on 28 August 2007. The resort has 3,000 suites, 1,200,000 sq ft (110,000 m2) of convention space, 1,600,000 sq ft (150,000 m2) of retail, 550,000 square feet (51,000 m2) of casino space – with 3,400 slot machines and 800 gambling tables and the 15,000-seat Cotai Arena for entertainment and sports events.
The lead architect for the Venetian Macao were Aedas and HKS, Inc. joint venture, who were responsible for the design, coordination and implementation of the project on site.


== Casino ==

The casino measures 546,000 sq ft (50,700 m2). It is further divided into four themed gaming areas—namely, Golden Fish, Imperial House, Red Dragon and Phoenix. The casino consists of over 6,000 slot machines and 800 gambling tables.
The hotel offers a club called Paiza Club which caters to premium guests. The club comes with its own entrance, lobby, reception, and guest lifts to the rooms. The gaming area of the Paiza Club is divided into individual private gaming rooms each named for notable Asian cities and regions such as Yunnan, Guangzhou, Hong Kong, Singapore and Kuala Lumpur.
The guests of the club have exclusive access to the club dining outlet, the Paiza Club Dining & Lounge, which is open 24 hours a day.


== Design ==
The hotel uses Venice, Italy, as its design inspiration and features architectural replicas of various Venetian landmarks.


== Accommodation ==
The hotel tower offers 2,905 suites. The accommodation floors go from level 7 up to level 38. These floors are served by guest lifts.
Paiza suites are reserved for premium guests. The largest is the Presidente, a 12-bay suite with four bedrooms.


== Entertainment ==

The Cotai Arena (formerly known as the Venetian Arena) is an indoor arena, opened in 2007 with a seating capacity of 15,000. It hosts sporting events such as basketball, tennis, and boxing, as well as concerts and international televised awards shows.


=== Zaia ===
Zaia, a 90-minute stage production by the Canadian entertainment company Cirque du Soleil, ran between 27 August 2008 and 19 February 2012 in a custom-built theater at the Venetian Macao. The show, directed by Neilson Vignola and Gilles Maheu, featured a cast of 75 circus artists. The show's theme was a young girl's perception of the stars and planets, space and infinity, populated by otherworldly creatures. The theater housing the performance seated 1,800 spectators at a time.


== Controversies ==

On 12 November 2008, the gates were locked to the construction labour force from a variety of Asian countries as projects were suspended.  Hsin Chong, the project manager for the Venetian, laid off approximately 400 staff. As many workers had been there for less than two years, no severance was due.  The next day, Sands' president for Asia announced that up to 11,000 workers would be losing their jobs as the company was halting building projects in Macao.In 2010 the Chinese press reported that as part of a "sex-trade crackdown" authorities had found more than 100 prostitutes inside the casino.In early 2011 the United States Department of Justice and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission initiated an investigation into the Las Vegas Sands Corporation with respect to the compliance of its Macao properties with the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

text.wiki:
The A-Ma Temple is a temple to the Chinese sea-goddess Mazu located in São Lourenço, Macau, China. Built in 1488, the temple is one of the oldest in Macau and thought to be the settlement's namesake.


== History ==

The name Macau was thought to be derived from the name of the temple. It is said that when the Portuguese sailors landed at the coast just outside the temple and asked the name of the place, the natives replied Maa-gok or A-maa-gok (lit. "The Pavilion of the Mother"). The Portuguese then named the peninsula "Macau". The temple was well described in ancient Chinese texts, as well as represented in paintings, related to Macao. It is also one of the first scenes photographed in Macao.
In 2005, the temple became one of the designated sites of the Historic Centre of Macau, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.


== Architecture ==
The temple consists of six main parts: Gate Pavilion, the Memorial Arch, the Prayer Hall, the Hall of Benevolence (the oldest part of the temple), the Hall of Guanyin, Zhengjiao Chanlin - Buddhist Pavilion.

Recently visited this temple, I was disappointed by how man people were there . The smell of burning insence was over powering . A little steep as it is built into the side of a hill. I didn’t feel There was actually much of o see there

One more place for added to engaged site seeing. Nothing much to watch and do. Just have local site seeing to keep you engaged.

A-Ma is one of the nicest temple I have seen, small very authentic and if you get lucky you can see some ceremonies with the gong, bells etc Definitely a stop to do if visiting for real Macau

it is genuine, functioning, so it is noot just about the buildings and stones, but about the atmosphere of serene praying, so it demands quiet and respectful behaviour; lots of incenses, and people praying - in our case a pair praying for happy marriage they intend to start.
Was taken here by the tour. Quite interesting. Has a bit of climb but not too bad. There's a famous ba keshop nearby so you'll never go hungry

The culture and the building itself is interesting. The place has alot of history. it is not very big but you can always take a few picture. Very easy to get to.
Awesome tourist spot, you’ll see lots of things here (Chinese culture). One of a must see in Macau, great visit!

Serene and peaceful built on rocks. Just beside Maritime museum, so you can plan both. Very old temple with two levels.

Me and my friends went here to know what's inside, it is a small temple in Barra where you can see a lot of artifacts from there religion, and above the summit you'll see a buddha. If you want to have some quiet time, then this is the place.
Had our tour in China and passed by this small yet beautiful temple. It was quiet but there were a lot of people going there and lighting chinese candles.

We can start our journey from here and walking up the city till thr ruins. Is very pretty, next to the river.
Lovely temple. Bright and not too many people. Lovely area out the front with big trees to sit and be thankful.

What a lovely temple...was a very peaceful and calm experience for us..we visited with our family the place had a beautiful positive effect on us and we were very happy after our visit...follow us on instagram @ foodieandmoody for pictures
If you have time...you can come to this temple When I came it was raining...so there's no many people come.
Reminds u that Asians once shared a common culture before communism prevailed It's almost like any Buddhist or Hindu temple without a priest
nice place right in the city centre, easy to locate.. there are many shops also around where you can shop

It was really hot so we did not venture to the top, however you can tell how old this temple is, lots of incense burning. Take the time to look around.

A must visit to this temple when in Macau. Soak into the culture,heritage and history. A place of worship.

A Ma temple is dedicated to the Chinese sea goddess Mazu and is located in Macau. It was built in the 15th century and is one of the oldest temples in Macau. It's been well maintained and has 6 parts. It is believed that name Macau was derived from the name of the temple.

Happened to be walking along a street when I bumped into this little temple. It’s super cute and tiny, and I am not really sure why it’s such an attraction because it doesn’t really stand out. However, I didn’t go inside because I had nothing to cover my shoulders...it was HOT!
I always come here every time i visit Macau. Good to make a wish. Many foreigners come to worship. Recommended.
You can see history through your vision. If you believe in superstition, this temple is perfect! Recommend to wear comfortable shoes because you have to walk a lot

For adults this is an interesting place to visit to see the traditional and cultural aspects. However it is not so great fro the teenagers who became a little bored. Recommended for a ‘quick visit’ only.
we have visited temple during one day local tour of macau , first point to visit in tour , as described by local tour it was goddess of fisherman in macau , historical temple of macau

The temple is built into a hill and is across the street from the bay. It's right near busy residential buildings in the middle of the city. There's quite a few steps to get to the top but there are a few altars you can stop and look at along the way. If you take the Open Top
We have visited this temple during our macau tour and found the place fine. A good place if tour is planned with family.

This is located by the harbor and about 20 min walk from Ruins of St. Paul. Nothing exciting here, it is a temple for worship. It is not too large or grand so nothing much to see other than a temple. It has its historical significance and value.

Didn’t change a bit since our last visit about 10 years ago. A very nice place to visit at sunset. It is right next to Maritime Museum and a famous cuisine A Lorcha.

The name of Macau come for the name of that temple ma. Chacters curved on stone walls and cents taller than my height as well as cents in coils are worth to observe. Washroom is also retroic. Nearby cooky bakery is a must to try for good taste and reasonal price.
A great Temple in Macau along with many others. Located near the old fishing wharf. Busses are available as well as the shipping museum across the way.

very nice and very old temple, which is definitely worth visiting, it is located a distance from the bustling centre of Macau

This temple is very beautiful and serene, one of the most beautiful small temple i have seen. It is interesting because it has more chinese religions in it not just one. It is built like in stone caves with beuatiful inscriptions on them. It is worth a visit.
This one is a small temple but very soulful and peaceful. The main offering is incense and the spiral ones look and smell beautiful!
Many followers with incense and tributes - built into the hillside so walk up the steps to see it all. From here we caught a bus to Macau Tower

The A-Ma temple is part of our local sight-seeing tour. The temple is ok and it is nice to visit it. Nothing outstanding though.
Unfortunately this temple really didn't appeal to our family and certainly didn't stand up to the write up it received in the Lonely Planet.
in all the excitement of macao,one place is at least serene.the incense rounds are a must watch.a definite pause.

The theme is really not much at all but I gave it 5 stars because of the old copper bowl which if you handle correctly makes the water dance we couldn't do it but one person did. Great fun watching others try.

Traditional Chinese temple in Macau. peaceful place to enjoy spiritual awakening in the commercial city of Macau

Historical place with many gods to pray to give you peace and luck. Helpful people there to teach you how to pray. One of the must visit place in Macau.

One of the attractions of the city of Macao is A-Ma temple as the city got its name from this temple. Its a nice temple with peaceful environment. Its worth a visit.
Very peaceful atmosphere away from the hustle and bustle of city crowd and casinos. Provides with a touch of Chinese prayers and things used. A different and much needed experience in Macau

Historically significant site to visit. It's about 10min to the top of the temple with lots of steps. There is a bakery there that sells the best fresh Portuguese Egg Tarts a must try when in Macau.

OK temple, but only as a curio if you are travelling to Macau for the first time. Otherwise, there's better and more interesting in any other part of South East Asia.

This temple is very popular for Macau people and also tourists. You can enjoy and walk around the temple It takes time around 30 minutes to visit this temple.

Made the effort to visit this temple as it's so famous in Macao. Disappointing, in my view as very small and insignificant, excuse my ignorance.
Nice historic temple built into the side of the hill, so lots of steps, Mostly outside with several altars, lots of incense burning.

Been here for ages, a great place for Chinese praying session. Welcome all visitor no matter what races you are. They have wishing tree corner for visitors too.

visited this place because we took tour. Guide took us to near bakery shop where you can have home made bakery items. Temple worship with burning candle can be done.
Not too much impression just quiet with sea view and temple located in the hill. Not too much building improvement and renovation

Very beautiful architecture and nice place for taking a rest from your city tour. Have a seat and watch the pilgrims coming in. climb up the hill and ahve a good look at the temple

text.wiki:
The Macao Giant Panda Pavilion (Chinese: 澳門大熊貓館; Portuguese: Pavilhão do Panda Gigante de Macau) is a zoo in Seac Pai Van Park, Coloane, Macau, China. It is located at the Macao Zoo. The Panda Pavilion is a nature park containing multiple animal species ranging from gorillas, flamingos, monkeys, and of course the famous pandas. Admission is free to see the animals.


== Architecture ==
The pavilion is shaped like a giant fan in an area of 3,000 m2. It consists of indoor activity quarters, outdoor yard and indoor exhibition area.


== Facilities ==
The pavilion is equipped with gift shop.


== Opening time ==
The pavilion opens everyday from 10:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.


== See also ==
List of tourist attractions in Macau


== References ==


== External links ==
Macao Giant Panda Pavilion

text.wiki:
Luís de Camões Garden (Chinese: 白鴿巢公園, Portuguese: Jardim de Luís de Camões) is a public park in Santo António, Macau. It is the oldest park in the territory, covering 20,000 square metres (220,000 sq ft) of space.
Camões Grotto is the former home of 16th century Portuguese poet Luís de Camões and one time Macau resident.
The facility includes the Macao Public Library  Wong Ieng Kuan Library in Luís de Camões Garden (Biblioteca de Wong Ieng Kuan no Jardim Luís de Camões Garden; 白鴿巢公園黃營均圖書館)


== References ==


== See also ==
List of oldest buildings and structures in Macau
trip: Camoes Grotto & Gardens looked like it is usually a nice leafy area to take a break but renovations were taking place. We were also disappointed that we couldn't see the statue of the first Korean Catholic priest Andrew Kim.

I gained a strong sense of tranquility and calm from the whole of this charming area, but especially from the delightful Garden and Grotto. It was an oasis of relaxation, light years away from the nearby 24 hour permanent madness of Contemporary Macau. This harked to an earlier,

There are a handful of nice city parks and rural areas around or near the Historic Centre of Macau. One of these is the Cameos Garden and Grotto at Camões Square just north of the Ruins of St. Paul's. This garden is named after the historic Portuguese poet Luis Camões. Here you

Camoes Gardens are well worth visiting with shady walkways, Pavilion, grotto, sculpture , fountain, lookout tower and lovely plants. Many locals come here to exercise on the machines as you enter the main gate, as well as others performing tai chi. It is one of the oldest parks
Seek it out... it’s a beautiful park with lots of places to sit out the heat of a Macao day. A number of different levels, and lots of little nooks and crannies to discover.

Surrounded by original old buildings, this botanical garden with its labeled trees and shrubs is a restful respite from the bustle of the newer parts of Macau. The grotto is a fine tribute to Portugual’s greatest poet. Camoens actually composed much of his epic poem in that

Not necessarily on the ‘tourist radar,’ this urban park/garden is worth a visit. There are several levels to this park - all accessible via stairs or sloping pathways. There are plenty of places to sit as benches sit the walking pathways. This is a local’s park as people were
This garden is bigger than it looks. A pleasant place to wander, Very busy with locals when we were there just a few days before Christmas,
Quite nice garden, with certain parts elevated, so we will feel that we hike a hills. Locals play with their kids and pets, while tourist like me observe the nice air.

After a walking tour through all of old Macau, we undertook the final leg and were so happy we did. Camoes Garden is absolutely beautiful, and being off the beaten track (beyond the ruins of St Paul's) it is largely underpopulated by tourists. The locals hang out there playing
A nice garden popular among local. There is not much to see here, but on the back of the garden there are many interesting little Buddhist temples.

Small gardens with mosaics sonnets engraved in stone and grotto with his bust. There are several gym machines for people to use. It seems a popular place for elderly and moms with children. It's close to the Santo Antonio Church.

This garden is popular among the locals, but I don’t think it is for tourists. There is nothing in this garden other than to walk or jog. The local elder people spend time here playing cards and gambling. The grotto which is a formation of 3 rocks is the only thing to see here.

This garden is named after the national Portuguese poet Luis de Camoes. He was supposed to live here some time and write on his work Os Lusiadas in the cave. Nowadays there is still his statue. You will find people doing their exercises or just sitting around. Very relaxed

Dedicated to the famous Portuguese poet Luis de Camoes who lived in Macau for a brief while and composed his epic poem "Os Lusíadas" here, the park is the largest in Macau and covers around 20,000 square meters. The park is a short walk from the Ruin's and is easily reached by

It's just an urban park. I liked the calm atmosphere and when we arrived there, everyone was working out. There are some beautiful altars in the back, so if you get the chance go there, it's not so far from the main entrance. The garden is very well preserved anyways.

I grew up learning about the Portuguese and their history. Be in a place that people says that Luis de Camoes wrote part of his most famous book is huge. The place is beautiful and nice to spend some time.

Ruínas da Antiga Catedral de São Paulo( 大三巴 ) is overcrowded. But just walk 5 minutes away to the Camoes Garden. The park is open from 6am to 10pm daily. Camoes Garden is most popular park in Macau, is frequented from dawn to dusk by tai chi enthusiasts, palm readers, lovers,

Camões is a 16th century Portuguese writer (the Portuguese Shakespeare or Cervantes, one can say). This beautiful garden was made in his honour, as it is supposed that he wrote part of his masterpiece "The Lusiads" here. You can read parts of his works as you walk through the

One of reasons we like to visit Camões Garden in Macau is to see the 10 cobblestone engravings which represent cantos of the important historical poet, Luis de Camões. The park is open from 6am to 10pm daily. You can find these surrounding the grounds around the large statue

Excellent garden among the modern infrastructure... unique part is the statue adorned to a korean martyr... dont know much about history but I found that a bit unusual...If you happen to live in Macau for work or otherwise you should visit this ... also good views of sea....

The Camoes Garden and Grotto is a very welcome green oasis in this busy city. There are paths for strolling and viewpoints across the river and the city, as well as quiet corners to sit in. the main monuments are to Camoes and to the Korean martyr St. Andrew Kim Taegeon.
This area is actually well-guarded from the noise of the city. There are a lot of plants, people doing tai chi EVERYWHERE, and the statues and grottos. Good for a break.

This was a great little place to escape the burning sun and take a peek at life in Macau away from the casinos and shops. Men sitting around playing cards, kids being kids, women doing their exercises. I loved it.

Grotto is a strong word. It is a nice stroll through small gardens on undulating land but this is not really worth making a big trek to find. Some nice views from the top but it is really over the top as a venue. Easy walk from st Paul's. It was a little Romantic for us but

Lovely park - a great place to relax within a lush green surrounding; the park also provides lovely vista of the city. Definitely worth a stop and a better place to visit in comparison to the dismal Casa Garden.

Macau is a very crowded place and this beautiful garden will take you out of that as soon as you enter. There is a bit of climbing up and down the paths throughout the gardens, but the views are beautiful and the garden rather tranquil. Take a break and enjoy the peace and quiet.
Really impressed by this historical location. Also interesting for me was the the protestant cemetary and the british east india old mansion in between..... Old macau was a cool place...

I love this garden, I just do! I lived in Macau for a bit, so this was one of my favourite places to go, have a pic-nic, read a book, etc etc. Close by there's also the protestant cemetery, a very nice place as well. This garden is really quiet and peaceful, I miss it very much!

text.wiki:
Taipa (Chinese: 氹仔, Cantonese: [tʰɐ̌m.t͡sɐ̌i̯]; Portuguese: Taipa, pronounced [ˈtajpɐ]) is an island in Macau, presently united with the island of Coloane by reclaimed land known as Cotai. Administratively, the boundaries of the traditional civil parish Freguesia de Nossa Senhora do Carmo are coterminous with that of former Taipa Island.


== Geography ==
Taipa is 2.5 kilometres (1.6 miles) from Macau Peninsula and east of the Lesser Hengqin Island of Zhuhai, Guangdong Province. Macau International Airport, University of Macau, Macau Jockey Club and Macau Stadium are situated in Taipa.

Area: 6.33 square kilometres (2.44 sq mi) (1.5 by 3.5 kilometres (0.93 by 2.17 miles))
Population: 70,000Most Chinese settlement of Taipa occurred during the Southern Song Dynasty, while the Portuguese occupied the island in 1851. Prior to land reclamation, Taipa consisted of two islands: Greater Taipa and Lesser Taipa.
The 159.1-metre (522.0-foot) Taipa Grande Hill (大潭山) is to the east, and Taipa Pequena Hill (小潭山) to the west. Central Taipa is a plain as a result of siltation and land reclamation. Initially Taipa was connected to Coloane Island only by the Estrada do Istmo (路氹連貫公路) causeway; but the area called Cotai, built on reclaimed land from 2004 and which is home to mega-resorts, casinos, and convention and exhibition centres, has now connected the two islands into one piece of land. Taipa is connected to peninsular Macau by Governador Nobre de Carvalho Bridge, Friendship Bridge and the Sai Van Bridge.
Taipa is predominantly a growing residential area with many new apartment complexes, mostly up-scale, under construction as of 2006. As a new town of Macau, Taipa has better city planning than Macau Peninsula; however, many people choose to live in Macau Peninsula since most of the famous schools are located there.


== The names of Taipa ==
In Cantonese, Taipa has been known by many names over time, including 龍環 (Lung Waan, meaning "Dragon Ring"), 雞頸 (Gai Geng, "Chicken's neck"), 潭仔 (Taam Jai, "Pool"), and 龍頭環 (Lung Tau Waan, "Dragon's-Head Ring").
The Portuguese and English name "Taipa" comes from the Chinese pronunciation of 氹仔 in Min Nan /tiap-á/ (similar to "tiamp-a") then became "Taipa". The putonghua pinyin for 氹仔 is dàngzǎi, and this is how the island is referred to in Mandarin. Both the character 氹 and the alternative form 凼 mean cesspit, but are obsolete in modern Chinese, and only used in relation to Taipa and the Macau-Taipa Bridge (澳氹大桥 àodàng dàqiáo). The character 氹, or 凼 (often used in Mainland Chinese texts), is often missing from mobile phone and computer input systems.
Another version according to legend, comes from an exchange between early Portuguese settlers on Taipa and local Chinese settlers. The Portuguese asked the Chinese the name (nome in Portuguese) of the place. The Chinese settlers were local grocery shopkeepers and spoke no Portuguese, but took the Portuguese nome for the Chinese 糯米, "sticky rice", which is pronounced similar to nome in Cantonese. Thinking the Portuguese settlers were asking if they sold sticky rice, the Chinese responded with "大把," pronounced "daai ba" in Cantonese, meaning "a lot." The Portuguese, hearing the response, took this to be the name of the place. There is, however, no historical evidence to support this story. "Taipa" is also what the Portuguese call the clay-mud, rammed into moulds, used to build mud houses in Portugal in times gone by, in recent times referred to as Rammed Earth.
It is also worth noting that, as the great majority of the population in Taipa and Macau is Chinese; however, there is a growing community of expatriates living in Taipa who work at the casinos on the Cotai Strip or at the schools and universities. Most people refer to this island by its Cantonese name, "Tamzai", and most taxi drivers and bus drivers will not understand if asked how to go to "Taipa."


== Education ==


=== Primary and secondary schools ===
Public preschool and primary school:

Escola Luso-Chinesa da Taipa (氹仔中葡學校) - Preschool and primary schoolPrivate tuition-free primary and secondary schools:

Macau Anglican College - Preschool through secondary
Escola Cáritas de Macau (明愛學校) - Special education
Escola Dom João Paulino - Preschool and primary school
Fong Chong School of Taipa (Escola Fong Chong da Taipa; 氹仔坊眾學校) - Preschool through senior secondary school
Hou Kong Middle School Macau Affiliated English School (濠江中學附屬英才學校)
Macau Pooi To Middle School Taipa Elementary School Branch (澳培道中學氹仔小學分校)
Pui Va Middle School (Escola Secundária Pui Va; 培華中學) - Preschool through secondary school
Macao Sam Yuk Middle School - Primary and secondary school
Affiliated School of the University of Macau (Escola de Aplicação Anexa à Universidade de Macau; 澳門大學附屬應用學校) - Preschool through secondaryPrivate non-free primary and secondary schools:

The International School of Macao - Located in Block K of the Macau University of Science and Technology - Preschool through secondary
School of the Nations - Preschool through secondary and special education


=== Colleges and universities ===
Macau University of Science and Technology (MUST), Institute for Tourism Studies, and City University of Macau are located in Taipa. University of Macau (UM), on Hengqin Island, which is part of Taipa (Nossa Senhora do Carmo), but geographically separate from Taipa.


=== Public libraries ===
The parish has two public libraries operated by the Macao Public Library system. Taipa Library (Biblioteca da Taipa; 氹仔圖書館), which began trial operations on 15 April 2015 and opened officially on 1 September of that year, occupies 2,200 square feet (200 m2) of space in the basement of Taipa Central Park (Parque Central da Taipa; 氹仔中央公園). Wong Ieng Kuan Library in Taipa (Biblioteca de Wong Ieng Kuan da Taipa; 氹仔黃營均圖書館) occupies 1,080 square metres (11,600 sq ft) of space on the second and third floors of Hei Loi Tang Plaza (喜來登廣場). The library, which had its construction funded with donations from the Wong Ieng Kuan Foundation (Fundação Wong Ieng Kuan; 黃營均基金會), opened on January 2005.

		


== Infrastructures ==
Macau Refuse Incineration Plant


=== Transport ===
Macau International Airport
Taipa Ferry Terminal
Macau Light Rail Transit


=== Healthcare ===
Health centres operated by the Macau government in Taipa include Centro de Saúde dos Jardins do Oceano (海洋花園衛生中心), Centro de Saúde Nossa Senhora do Carmo-Lago (湖畔嘉模衛生中心), and Posto de Saúde para os Idosos Taipa (氹仔老人保健站).


== Tourism ==

Altira Macau
Cunha Street
Macau Olympic Aquatic Centre
Macau Stadium
Museum of Taipa and Coloane History
Taipa Houses–Museum
Macau Jockey Club
Taipa Fort (砲台)


=== Religious ===
Pou Tai Un Temple (菩提園 or 菩提襌院): named after bodhi tree
Kun Yam Temple (觀音岩)
Tin Hau Temple (天后宮)
Sam Po Temple (三婆廟): dedicated to the elder sister of Tin Hau
Pak Tai Temple (北帝廟): dedicated to the Taoist God of the North
Four-faced Buddha (四面佛): purchased from Thailand in 1985
Church of Our Lady of Carmel (嘉模聖母教堂): Catholic churchOther healthcare services include:

Macau University of Science and Technology Hospital
Posto de Urgência das Ilhas
Kiang Wu Hospital Taipa Medical Centre


== See also ==
Taipa Ferry Terminal
List of islands and peninsulas of Macau


== References ==


== External links ==
 Media related to Taipa at Wikimedia Commons
 Taipa travel guide from Wikivoyage

text.wiki:
The Na Tcha Temple (Portuguese: Templo Na Tcha; Chinese: 大三巴哪吒廟), built in 1888, is a Chinese folk religion temple in Santo António, Macau, China dedicated to the worship of the deity Na Tcha.
The Na Tcha Temple was built in homage to the child god of war. It is believed that it was built to put an end to the plague ravaging the region during that time.The small traditional Chinese temple is a simple, single chamber building measuring 8.4 meters (28 ft) long and 4.51 meters (14.8 ft) wide. The entrance porch opens to the temple building measuring 5 meters (16 ft) in depth. The building is painted gray, with few ornamentations, except for paintings on walls under the entrance porch. The temple's roof, rising five meters, is of the traditional yingshan style. True to traditional Chinese architecture, the Na Tcha has protective ceramic animal figures on its ridge.Na Tcha Temple is located behind the Ruins of St. Paul's, remains of a principal Jesuit cathedral in the region, serving as one of the best examples of Macau's multicultural identity. In 2005, the temple became one of the designated sites of the Historic Centre of Macau enlisted on the UNESCO World Heritage List.


== See also ==
