text.wiki:
Saint Dominic's Church (Chinese: 板樟堂; Portuguese: Igreja de São Domingos) is a late 16th-century Baroque-style church that serves within the Cathedral Parish of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Macau.  It is located in the peninsular part of the city at the Largo de São Domingos, situated near the Leal Senado Building.
The construction of the church was finished in 1587 and was overseen by three Spanish Dominican priests.  Due to renovations and reconstruction, the current structure dates back to the early 17th century.  The church is listed as one of the 29 sites that form the Historic Centre of Macau, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.


== History ==
The church was established in 1587 by three Spanish Dominican priests who arrived from Acapulco, Mexico.  It was the scene of violence in 1644, when a Spanish officer—loyal to the King of Spain and opposing the colony's determination to stay allegiant with Portugal after the dissolution of the Iberian Union—entered the church in order to seek refuge from an angry mob.  He was promptly murdered at the foot of the altar while mass was being celebrated.  Sixty-three years later, in 1707, the Dominicans supported the Pope's stance with regards to the Chinese Rites controversy.  This was in opposition and defiance to the view of the Bishop of Macau, who subsequently excommunicated them.  When soldiers were sent to the church in order to uphold this ruling, the friars responded by closing the church for three days and throwing rocks to repel them.The first Portuguese-language newspaper in China—A Abelha da China (The China Bee)—was published at St. Dominic's on September 12, 1822.  The church closed down in 1834 when monastic orders were dissolved and expropriated to the government, who then converted it into barracks, a stable and an office for public works.  However, it later reopened and was given many works of sacred art from other religious orders dissolved back in Portugal.The church underwent renovation in 1997 and a museum was added alongside the church.


== Architecture ==
The church of St. Dominic was built in a Baroque style and is noted for its mixture of European and local Macanese features in its design.  This is demonstrated in the church's use of Chinese-style roof tiles and doors made of teak.  The church's high altar features a statue of the Madonna and Child as the centrepiece and is flanked by wood and ivory-carved statues of several saints.


== Museum ==
The Treasure of Sacred Art Museum was established as part of the 1997 renovation and is located inside the church's bell tower.  It contains approximately 300 religious works of art and artifacts.

trip: This Catholic Church was one of the stops on our day trip to Macau. The church is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and construction was completed in 1587. The exterior is a bright yellow and white - Our guide told us that the buildings are repainted every year/every other year.

To be honest, the facade does not look very appealing, and worse still, you'd think it is under massive construction, which is true to some extent. BUt there is a rather lovely museum inside, (free of charge), with exhibits of the old church, and all the old relics of church

The inside of St. Dominic’s Church enabled us to escape the tourist crowds that had no interest in the cultural sights. Four floors of the church was displaying old Catholic artifacts that one would not expect to see in China.

always crowded in day time but you can light a candle inside the church for at-least 25mop and write a message on it they will let it stay on the altar until the light is off .. its a nice place to visit very near to ruin of st. paul ⛪️⛪️

The church was not open. It was in a old square that become a tourist attraction because of the Portugal traditional design. A good place to walk around. There were many shops that selling tradition Macau snacks, lot of free sample for you to try!

I enjoyed seeing this church and exploring the interior though I didn't see the actual church part just the two floors of museum - The main church part was closed for construction or renovation. Gorgeous vibrant yellow fascade right in the heart of the historic district. Free to

Going to Senado Square we passed by St. Dominic Square right in front of St. Dominic Church. Luckily there were Police Officers performing to the delight of the people. We stayed and watched couple of plays which can be likened to an orchestra. Would like to stay until

St. Dominic's Church colored in vibrant yellow stone and white mortar exterior is one of Macau's most famous churches. Located in senado square.The church is a museum full of Catholic art, sculptures, and tools used by its priests for hundreds of years. No entry fee. Open from
Nice to stroll around and take photos of the Portuguese decoration and historical city centre. It’s also a pleasant walk close by to Ruins of St Paul’s and Senado Square.
This is a nice little church in the famous square. The architecture of it was a marvelous piece by itself.

St. Dominics Church in the heart of the Historic City is a beautiful way to take a moment and realize not only how fortunate you are to be travelling to this beautiful place but absorb the beauty and the calmness it gives you.

It was simple but elegant church. I love the image of our Lady holding the rosary. Made me feel that she was welcoming us in God's home. I wish I could attend the mass but we have to leave so soon, maybe next time.
It's a good place to visit while you are here. The place is quite calm and you do have time to review everything.

This is right at the Square and definitely worth visiting. We couldn't spend a lot of time as it was pouring rain but got to see a bit of it quickly. If you're already at the square would recommend going and visiting the church!
Stands up uniquely in the Denado Square is a yellow picturesque St Domic's Church. The Church is famous for its decorated woodern ceiling and sacred art. The Church is tge World Hetitage of Macau.

Some people only take pictures of the church's facade, because of the bright yellow color. The church is open to public, and it is free. I did went inside, because I just wanted to check it out. Turned out, you can light a candle here. Buy the candle in the church office, just

A visit to St. Dominic's Church showcases the church's historical past as well as its present day relevance to Macau. Macau is more than its casinos, world class real estate, cuisines and shopping. Located in busy Senado Square which is crowded day and night with tourists and
This is a pretty church in the city centre, which you will find as you are walking through the streets of Macau or while on your way to the Ruins of St Paul's.

This church is located in the historic Macau. It is certainly worth a visit if you are in the area. It is well preserved and you will find stained glass paintings and sculptures related to the Christian faith. Do note that this is a place of worship and one should therefore be
Don't miss this place even though you are not christian , feeling holy place to keep a pray and you will not remember about how busy in downtown area
Beautiful heritage, well maintained. There are a lot of shops around - shopping & eating, connecting to Senado Square.
Visited as part of tour, this church is in the middle of a square and very quaint. Would recommend taking the time to walk through, very peaceful and stunning architecture.

Once more linked to the Portuguese heritage of Macau - a place more interesting for those looking to know a bit more about the history of place. So here it is : - you will find it close to the Senado Square in Old Town Macau - you can enter free of charge - so visiting is

I like the Portugal style church in Macau. You don't feel you are in Asia. The colour is sharp. We didn't go inside but just take photos outside. We spent about 20 minutes only. It was enough for us. Perhaps it isn't that interesting for European as they might prefer something
yeah, i must admit the historical centre is still charming...the floor, the streets and this church in the middle of the city still witness Portugal presence in Asia
Old church, in the senado square, must visiting place, this place a active church, in the 2nd and 3rd floor there is a small museum with the ornaments, statue, symbols etc you must see
The church is so remarkable and invites all admirers to see her elegance and beauty. The museum upstairs was quite interesting.
I'm not catholic and haven't been inside the church, but the facade of the building is nice, it doesn't look old! They perform light festival infront of the facade of Church and it's good...
The church was going through some minor restorations but was still well-kept. It was clean and serene.
Old church that become a museum for catholic heritage in Macau Nice to walk through this place and appreciate the catholic heritage in Macau.

This is located near Senado Square and it is one of the heritage buildings in Macau, built in 1587 with Baroque Architecture. It is quite crowded and not really worth a special trip unless you are passing by.

The most popular church to visit within Macao World Heritage is St. Dominic's located at the east end of Senado Square. Even the quickest of visits to Macau World Heritage should include a stop at St. Dominic's Church. Originally founded in 1597, the present church was built by
Beautiful building and much loved and cared for. The churches in Macau are all very special. A must see as part of the incredible Portuguese history.

This church is between The Ruins of St Paul and Senado Square. It is beautifully painted on the outside and has its own small square in front of it. A nice oasis to escape the crowds for contemplation and / or prayer. A security guard was present . Well worth a visit.

This church near St Paul and Largo de Senado is another fragment of Portugal’s influence in Macau. There is not much to do here but take picture and appreciate this piece of architecture. Love the view though and I like how it’s color seems to light up the mood.

Very nice scene, historical value and marvellous building. The church is very beautiful, especially the glass painting inside the church. Please remember to keep quiet inside the church and aware the dress code, no skirt, no shorts and no sexy dressing.

We visited this church while visiting the historic center if Macau. This church was the first Christian Church to be built in China. It was built by Dominican priests in 1587. The church is just beautiful, inside and out. It is free to visit the church and its museum. We
Place to be if you want to have some historic memories while visiting Macau Just a must see sight seeing
st.Dominic's resonates with historic atmosphere and was the highlight of our recent walk around the City Centre, as we had not explored it at any great length before. It truly is worth the effort.

While walking to go to St. Paul's ruin, you will find St. Dominic's church with stunning colours. I entered the church during my visit and suddenly I felt the peacefulness of the church. It was so quiet inside the church. You can pray or take photos of the church interior.
St. Dominic's Chrich is a beauty, very clean. You can go inside too. The architecture is very detailed and well kept. A lot of people, go to see early!

nothing very special about this church (for an European visitor), except the location in the centre of the old Macao; of course it is a symbolic remnant of times that will irreversible end in 2049, and offers a quiet place to escape the crowds, sit, relax, pray, cool down (on a

Old church in city center, sometimes have orchestra playing classical music inside... also have a religious museum exposition at the building and where you can access it by the door on the right side beside the main gate door. When there is a religiuous ceremony access to the
This one is one of many nice building in Macau. i wasn't able to go inside but the outside look very nice. with all the architecture element. Great for selfie picture
Old classic church, right in the city center, if you like history like us, you will like it, maybe you are as lucky as us when violins were playing inside

I asked my boyfriend to come inside so I could pray solemnly in the house of God. And Unlike any other tourist spot churches, I can tell that st. Dominic church maintain it's quietness with the few guards around. It was not crowded and there's definitely a place for you to kneel
This place is really crowded, but around there is a lot to see. therefore take a walk and expolre all the small streets around the church! Enjoy
This is a very old church and has a lot of colonial characteristics worth visiting even just for a few minutes to get away from the crowds. The church has Mass every evening.

This old church contains a museum of religious artefacts on its upper three levels. It is worth a visit to view silver ornaments and items relating to the history of this church which spans several hundred years.
This place is in Senado Square on the way to Remain of St Pauls. Nice place to be. Architecture is good. Good Photo Op outside the church.

There are several tropical baroque churches in Macau but this is the best one. The façade is brightly colored and the inside is truly beautiful. The environments are also lovely. If you just have time for a church in Macau, go for this one

This was a brightly colored church in the heart of the historic Macau district that as has been given the UNESCO world heritage designation. While there were lots of tourists outside taking pictures when I went inside it was much quieter and much less crowded. First thing I
Beautiful church in the heart of the old city. A lot of signs around to other attractions in case you get lost.

This church is truly beautiful but I think the actual beauty is inside. I'm not overly religious but the inside space is mesmerising in all it's pomp and glory. There is even a Portguese Nun selling religious artifacts for religious souls. Just make sure that your party is

This was an interesting church. What I found most unique was the confessional, which was a box the priest sat in (and it appeared he had to be quite small) with kneelers on either side. This led me to believe the confessions weren't all that private. Otherwise it was similar to

Nobody in the area knew what time the church opens. There was no sign of church schedule of opening or closing. No schedule of masses too. It would have been nice if there were since this was located at the center and very near St Paul Ruins. Many Catholic faithful would be

St Dominic’s Church was closed when we passed by on our way to the ruins of St.Paul’s Carhedral. Tourists abound and were all stopping by to have their pictures taken. We joined the bandwagon. It has a baroque architectural design with a mixture of European and local Macanese
i visited with my friends and family, the lighting is good when evening. had a chance to comeback in the morning because in evening it is close
Nice church about midway between Senate Square and Ruins of St Paul's, so it makes a for nice stop and visit inside the church and church museum which is free.

This church provides respite even to atheists like me when the weather and crowds outside are equally stifling. The interior is impressive and it's definitely worth going up the stairs to look at the huge array of Christian iconography on display. It's also quite striking at
The St. Dominic's Church looks really beautiful in yellow and you will love the symmetry in its design. Its well maintained yet you will find a sense of old world charm about it..
It was a simple, but beautiful yellow church founded by 3 spinaches back in 1587. It was only a few minutes walk from the Largo de Senado. The streets around the area was worth to check it out.

The small pocket of colonial cultural influences evident in this historic section of Macao is all the more fascinating considering the vast differences w the Chinese. A quick walkthrough, one can do the tour within 30 to 60 minutes and any extension can only be accounted for by

We spent a Day walking around Macau, we stumbled upon this church, so cool, such neat architecture, There is a small museum inside the church that we didn't know about either with various historical and religious pieces, so definitely walk inside if it is open, a lot of stair
This is a great place to visit to see the church and to see how well maintained it has been kept after all this time!! It is in a very busy tourist spot but a must to see!!

It's a church with its history and has been stood up there for long time. The church itself is built beautifully and it is very well maintained. The interior is also nice and peaceful. It's a place worth to pay a visit even for non-Catholic people as it is just located in the

This Domenican order old Portuguese church is still operating and visitors will need to respect certain things if you are to visit eg take off hats etc. If you go up the stairs to the higher floors you are able to see a number of religious artifacts that the church has preserved.

Actually, this area is too touristy, so much people crossing around that makes photobombs, so you must came early for the best shot. Surrounded by shops & cafes this area is the perfect place to visit. Walks from Senado Square, arrived in this place, get some walks & you will

St. Dominic church was built in a mixture of European and local Macanese features in its design. The church's high altar features a statue of the Maria and Child as the centrepiece and is flanked by two statues. Two antique chandeliers hanging from the high ceiling as the
It is call 玫瑰堂. You may go inside for visit. It is located behind Senado Square. The famous Ginger Milk shop YiShun is just next to the shop beside this church.
Lots of pictures were being taken outside, but the inside is worth a visit too. One should remember though that it is a place of worship
St Dominc's Church was beautiful we passed by it while walking around Macau old town. Worth the visit.

This bright and yellow coloured church is located between Senado square and the Ruins of St Paul's. Lots of tourists have their photos taken in front of this church. Inside the church, it is cool and quiet. An interesting fact is that it is here that the first Portuguese

A rather simple church with basic architecture. Nothing much. Just a place to note while browsing. Rather popular as it is close to the Ruins of St. Paul. You can go in to take a rest if you are tired.

Just a short distance and on the Senado Square is located the church which is dedicated to Our Lady of Rosary, Mother Mary. This was established in the year 1587 by three Dominican priest which originated from Mexico. There is the short history which is inscribed which is placed

This interesting church about halfway between Largo do Senado and the Ruins of St. Paul dates back to 1587. It was founded by a group of Dominican priests who came from Mexico. The yellow exterior with green doors make quite an impression as you round the corner of the (crowded)
This is one of many historic churches in Macau which are worth visiting. We had a short stop here on our walking tour of the historic centre.

You should stop to briefly see this lovely 16th century Baroque-style church. The interior is relatively simple but adorned by some nice details. The main altar features a statue of the Madonna and Child . Dominant colors are white and golden-yellow. We did not see Treasure of

It looks like you got middle century era. Very old european architecture in Chinese Macau. But it looks in harmony and very nice. Many people come there and you can get picture only with neighbours)))

On the way up the hill to see the Saint Paul's ruins you come across this gem. Lovely church with a museum off to one side with a fair bit of history. Defiantly worth a look if you are interested in Macou's history
St. Dominic Church is situated in tourist spot so if you go there you can see many things and nearby Ruins of st. Paul
Both interior and exterior is well kept and it is beautiful. A nice visit even if you are not religious. It gets crowded so please be careful with your personal belongings.
Another example of a beautiful Portuguese building built in Macau at a time when the east met the west in harmony and respect.
Another icon of macau. Very near to Senado Square and Ruins of St Paul. Be warned of the large crowd though. Would prefer other churches in Macau that is more serene.
Church designed in the Baroque style situated at the end of the main square. Peaceful place given the crowds outside

When in the historic center of Macau, do not forget to pass by at St. Dominic's church not just to pray but upstairs at the backside there is a mini museum of old church things (ceborium, images, etc.). It can be easily found in the historic center of Macau.
A little piece of Portugal, very clean,lots of tourists, o'well just enjoy the adventure. Have fun people watching.
Though the looks and color is attractive from outside, the inside is just common. Some statues and high windows might be interesting.
The sanctuary is open to the public and is a short walk from the Fountain of Leal Senado on your walk up to St. Paul’s wall. The distinct yellow exterior is the benchmark site!

This chruch is on a picturesque square on the route between Senado Square and the ruins of St Pauls. It is an active church with fairly plain interior, but an elaborate exterior plaster design. The main altar and aisles are roped off, but a friendly security guard took my

Not too far from St. Paul's ruins, walking through the busy shops selling the famous pork jerky, local delicacies, local shops and restaurants, we arrived at this church. The interior was beautiful. A holy place in the center of the historical district, In the middle of the
A quaint church in the heart of the historic district of Macau. The seats are basic and the fixtures are very humble.
the place located along the street to St. Paul's Ruin, the road very nice decorated and very clean, completed with some branded shop
After walking up and down to Ruins of St Paul's, it was a great stop for my family. Calming, Cooling and Soothing!

An old church in the historic part of Macau & worth a look through. Free entry & easily accessible - no queuing. Not large but features a significant amount of wood in the interior including the ceiling. Small amount of historical information available outside about the church.
Quaint little historic church set in Saint Dominic's heritage site square, Peaceful and tranquil well with a view if ever you're in Macau
Nice example of local tropical architecture. Stop by on your stroll between Senado square and Saint Paul. There is also a good museum of sacred items if you are interested.
Located in the heart of the city in Senado Square. Perhaps the most beautiful church in Macau, was built to worship Our Lady of the Rosary.
Just 1 minute walk from Senado Square. Partly on renovation work but still a view at night. Great spot for photos and surrounded by shops and very touristy.

Me and my friend easily got to this church because literally its in the middle of the park. The place is really busy because it is surrounded by shops and food stalls. The church itself is just a typical church, big with old religious images and some old architectural design. We
worth spending a morning looking round soaking in the atmosphere loads of shops places to eat its friendly its vibrant and Macau
This was near a lot of other things I was going to so we popped in for a few minutes. It was pretty but seemed like countless other churches.
Go only if you have plenty of time. Its is basically a thick wall, not a room/building in which you can enter. You can walk down and to the street markets and buy souvenirs
Small but very nice, like things in Macau. It's well-preserved and located in a busy area where you can see a lot of other attractions as well.

I'm a Catholic , and I had the chance to meet priest Michael, and he is very nice and welcoming. I attended a mess in Portuguese. It was very cool to see all those Chinese people who speak Portuguese. Really cool and interesting experience
Its a small Beautiful Church, the whole area is beautiful and gives a good feeling. One should visit.
This is a beautiful old church with a beautiful altar, we looked for a candle to light but couldn't find where to get them from!

Saint Dominic's Church was great visit. The tour does not take long but shows wonderful details of history and of the local Architecture. This is a must see and very close to the city centre and other major tourist sites.
This church is tiny one. I like the yellow painting on outside wall. But nothing special about this church. It is next to the lago do senado.
this church is very simple, but simply beautiful and elegant. It's a good example of the colonial heritage of Macau. I guess that's a must see in Macau

Its a small beautiful church next to the Senado Square. You pass it by as you walk to the Ruins of St. Pauls. We didn't actually visit it, but did stop by to admire its beautiful exterior and the architecture.
Pretty small church but nothing special. Nice to look at and stop into on the way to the ruins of St. Paul.
This is a must go place for tourists. As it is located on the center of the city. And it built more than100years ago. So it is a heritage. It wlworth us to visit and learn.
I am not a religious person, but this was amazing and it is free as well. The artifacts here make the catholic churches in Europe look bad. It really is amazing Would recommend to all.

Located in the heart of Senado Square and was placed on world heritage list. We passed by this church on the way to Ruins of St. Paul. Crowded with tourist and we only observed the beautiful architecture from the outside.
a living monument.sadly being taken over by bossini and tissot.one wonders if these stores can get a little muted.
located near to ruins of st paul's church and can be reached there on foot from the church, appearance is quite colourfull
We just saw this building from outside. We didn't go in as it was closed. Its a nice place to walk around in the evening.
This church is located in the historic city center of Macau and is adjacent to Senado square. Peaceful and tranquil place with excellent Portugal architecture.

A very old church that is located within walking distance from St Paul Ruins, with a rich history and interesting architecture. They also have a small museum near the back of their church with Christian paintings and artwork. Worth a visit since its free, but you can consider
The church is located in the center of Senado square , the architecture its quite awesome and the color is so pretty

This church is on the way when going to St Paul's Ruins just after the Senado Square. The church's architecture usually makes every passerby to stop and take photos before continuing to the ruins. This is a functional church so approaching it with solemnity is needed especially
If you look for public toilet around ruins of st paul or senado square, good news, the toilet is behind this church

Very nice Church. You will found this Church on the way from Senado Square to Ruins of St Paul. Its around 5 mins walk from Senado to Ruins of St Paul. Along all the walkway there is shot lots can buy & drinks some small snacks.
I think it's the only church in Macau that allows you to move close to the altar area for photo taking or take a closer look at the altar setup. Simply great.
A beautiful church within Senado square, a good place to see the icons within the church and the adjacent museum of antique church treasures. I hope to get to attend a mass here one day.

For such a lovely and historic building, the church wasn’t as crowded as I had thought. The Ruins of St. Paul had dampened our spirits of the peace and tranquility of our Macau visit but it was restored after visiting St. Dominic’s. It was so lovely and had that strong European
The most beautiful church in Macao. A must see Unesco world heritage site in this former Portuguese colony.
I really felt like i was back in Faro when i went and visited this church, the bright yellow buildings were beautiful

This church was constructed since the days of the Portuguese colony. Situated within the very prominent Senando square, you can see massive amount of tourists visiting this beautiful church. It is one of the main landmarks of Macau. It's a must see. If you have not visited this
Lovely picture shot from the small square. Very nice inside. If you are of the faith a nice place to sit and reflect and perhaps say a prayer.

This place connected by a by lane from the Ruins of St. Paul is a colorful, cheerful centre teeming with tourists. Opposite the Senado Square. The connecting walk way is a small market place teeming with shops not very different from that you see in HKG.
Passed this beautiful colonial church on my way to largo de Senado. Almost missed it amongst the crowds. Lovely interior. Worth stopping by.
Walking up and inside you would think you were in Lisbon with the yellow walls and white trim. Smaller than you would think but it shows very standard european catholic architecture.
We visited this beautiful structure which is on the edge of the main mall in the old town area of Macau. The facade and interior are interesting and quite beautiful
The place will be crowded on weekend day and night. Shopping area for tourist and good for photo taking session.

Visiting the Old City Centre, we found St Dominic's church. While inside it looks like any church, the building's front is rather nice. It looks a but like these churches in Central America. It was surprising to see this in the heart of South East Asia, in Macau. Worth to stop

Firstly, the Immigration into Macau, horrendous guys, they think no sky to themselves, totally and absolutely absurdly rude. But once you cross them, DONT LET THEM AFFECT YOUR MOODS, you will be in paradise. The government and of course STANLEY HO the "king of Macau" has spared
I lived in a place where there are so many catholic churches around with different design and art. But this church is a nice one because of its history.
this was the least interesting place in Macau. It looked like your average catholic church. I did like the history behind it, but it wasn't all that great.

If you want to pray & have a quiet moment in the middle of a busy tourist area, this is the place to be. While it's open to tourists, noise & picture-taking inside are not allowed. The seating area is exclusive for those who would like to pray. Unfortunately, there's no Mass on
The interiors are sober and peaceful. The architecture is simple yet worth a look. The facade is painted bright yellow and you will not miss it.
Outside and inside of church full of people. However, it is peaceful and quiet when inside the church. Very beautiful architecture. I am not a Christian. But, it is worth a visit.
This Chapel really has a peaceful calm once you step in. They have a lovely museum upstairs which displays different artifacts which are sacred to the Catholic faith. Recommended to visit

This was a very nice find along the way from the historic city Centre to the Fortress. Started in the 16th century by some Dominican priests from Mexico, it has been renovated over the years and is a key part of the church community in Macau.
This is a great area for photographs and great restaurants. Bring your walking shoes and enjoy the day.

This is one of the signature buildings in Macau. You actually pass it on the way to the ruins.. we grabbed some takeaway food and just sat in front of the church and enjoyed the view. It was a Friday and it was not crazy crowded.

along the way to Ruins of St Paul from Senado Square, you will find a big yellow building with solid green door. it is the St Dominic's Church. the church is not big, not much frills or ornaments. but for me personally, it was memorable. you can take some time to pray or just
The facade of the church is lovely, great for photos. The inside is okay but still worth a visit (you can offer/light candles) inside the church.

This was my favorite of the buildings between the ruins of St Paul's and Senata Square. It is brought and cheerful and definitely draws the eye. The interior is markedly less ornate and rather basic but worth a quick peak.

The yellow facade attracted me as I was walking in Senado Square. Its very cool and quiet inside, the architecture is also interesting. Just make sure to be quiet as you visit so as not to disturb the worshippers who are praying.

Most people who visit this place as tourists would have come across this church on the walk up to St Paul's ruins. This church is a functional church and whilst it may not be as grand as the ones found in Europe, it is a place of peace and serenity. If you walk in, you can feel

This is a World Heritage Site, with a functional Catholic Church. Although most of the building was rebuild in the 1800, the church sends of vibes of dignity, holiness and a general sense of wellness once you set foot on its ground. One can witness the old style of the layout
Can take lots of pictures on the outside. They do not really let you in. I'm not sure on other days but we were let in for evening Mass. Mass is in Portuguese.
Coming from Europe we expected probably too much. The church is historic and old but not special. You would not even notice such a church in Europe.

Take a picture inside and outside the church. But the ceiling was plain unlike old church / cathedral as I expected it would be. When you get inside, it would be better to be not noisy since there would be people praying.

We popped in here, as I am sure many other visitors do, on the way up to finding the ruins of St Pauls; but I am so glad that we did as the ruins proved to be just that, with no spirituality at all, whereas this beautiful church was quiet and tranquil. Quite simple in its decor

Constructed in 1587, and now can be found at Largo Sao Domingos, I was very happy to be able to come inside and say a prayer. Amidst the busy, touristry and commercial atmosphere outside, it is peaceful inside. And was able to hear a Portuguese mass last February.
One of the historical churches in Macau. Nice statues inside and impressive architecture. Not very crowded inside. Good for picture taking at the facade. Portuguese influence in Macau.
Walked past this beautiful church on the way to the Ruins of St Paul. I went in and it blew me away. I wanted to go back and go there to attend the mass - hopefully soon :)

Simple Church in the heart of Macau but have interesting history. It's one of the oldest Catholic Church in Macau and established by three Spanish Dominican. Anyone is welcome to go inside the Church but make sure to give respect as others is praying. At the back of it also have

My sister and I were not able to enter the church which is very famous with its grand interior because when we went there it was undergoing renovation. But locals told us that when it is open, many visit and pray inside the church.

Visited this church during our stay. It feels like it doesn't fit the city of Macau, almost out of place with it's style. The church is peaceful, nicely decorated and is beautiful to walk through. It's a quick stop as you explore the square.

Church is very simple however I really like the exterior color of church certainly worth taking picture at its on your way to Famous Ruins of St Paul's with lot tourist, shops, restaurant, Bakery's around.
if you traveling to macua and you will go to st. paul ruins just drop there for additional attraction but just a typical church..

Visited this catholic church post the visit to Ruins of St. Paul- its one of the photogenic churches from outside with yellow contrast walls. The interiors are quite simple and basic. Not to spend too much time on this- I took pictures and walked around.
You won't miss it on your way to Ruins of St Paul's from Senado Square. The yellow and white church is one of the major Catholic churches in Macau.

We came across this church as we were going from Senado Square towards the Ruins of St Paul's, and were first attracted by the yellow facade. Inside the church has a high ceiling and is plain in decor rather than ornate and overembellished, giving an air of simplicity and

One of the attractions whilst wondering around old Macau, worth a quick pop in here. Nothing like the wealth you see in Rome and other Italian cities, but clearly is a reflection of a more simple, basic style of Catholicism. Not a 'must see' but if you are in the area, is

The church sits in between the ruins of St Paul's and Senado Square, and it definitely caught my attention although I was not looking out for it. The architecture sticks out even though the surrounding buildings are also of colonial style. I did not go in, but the facade is
Beautiful old church building. The venue for many concerts of classical music (free entrance!)/ If you want to touch the history of old Portugal and Macao - visit it!
You would pass by this church if you have been to the ruins of St Paul, so it's no effort to get there. Its presence adds to the beautiful atmosphere and environment of this lovely colonial area.

Was walking along Senado Square and saw many people were in and out of this church. Went in and found this church is interesting and special. Besides the is there floors of the church artifacts which you can go up floor to understand it.

We walked inside without knowing much about this church. When we entered inside than realize how big it is. Overall good experience. This is just on the way to our path so does not take extra effort to visit it. Partially crowded on a very busy street.
classic portuguese architecture piece , which has been well restored and talks about the Portuguese era in macau.
Only a very small area, so you can take few photos, the colour is nice. Very crowded during Xmas to Chinese New Year, lots of tourist.

St. Dominic's Church was built by three Spanish Dominican priests in 1590. The facade is painted yellow with green wooded doors. In 1644, a military officer, who supported the Spanish against the Portuguese was murdered during mass in the building. In 1707, the Dominicans sided

very nice place to spend, with family , but with too many tourists around, just taking pics, that too on a holiday not done !!!!!!!!!!!!!!

As you walk up to the ruins of St Paul from Senado sq. this church will be about half way in between. Nice church, adds to the atmosphere of the area, nothing spectacular but it would be a shame to just walk by it.
Nice church with old statues and right place for praying but sometimes too many tourist just taking picture and not able to be more calm and keep the silent

It is a beautiful church located near the senado square. It is small but very beautiful, you can smell the history there. I was not able to stay in a mass but just with the fact of being there is enough for realizing its greatness.
The church is clearly well looked after, and although a little garish from outside, it is pretty impressive inside. Definitely a nice church but nothing particularly blew me away.

The Church is ordinary from outside (though the green windows are pretty) but the interiors will make you gasp. it is grand and yet peaceful. the statues are beautiful and will leave you staring at them for many minutes. it is a place where you will want to sit and pray. the
Very pleasant looking church from the outside , beautiful and cool, inside. the feeling of peace is a welcome change from the bustling streets outside.
The church is pretty. Also go to the small exhibition (entrance on the right side), it has lots of Christian exhibits.

As you face the altar of the church, head to the right and out of the doors to find a stair case up. This leads to a collection of religious artifacts, but also, on the third floor, to a room that is simple and beautiful. It's interesting to reflect on how the visitors from

It's very simple but heartwarming. It's so different compare to church I've visited before (Sagrada Familia- Barcelona, several churches in Netherland, and some others in Italy). I personally like it and will come back if I have the chance cause I haven't really explored the

about 5 min walk from Senado Square. Small but Magnificent church which is still actively used for church services or Macau Music Festival. Nearby houses the 5 story museum of Sacred Art (free entrance)

St. Dominic's Church was made of baroque design resembling many Spanish-era churches in the Philippines but departing from the original natural heritage look, it was painted yellow and white to conform with most buildings within the Historic City Centre which all painted to look

This review is quite late. The St Dominic's Church is a lovely old church located within the historic centre of Macau. Just like most buildings it's ochre and white exterior paint gives it a fresh and neat look and the Baroque-style architecture is impressive. Many souvenir

The church is the oldest in Macau built in the late 16th century in the Baroque style. The beautiful yellow is stunning in the sun and transports you to Europe when walking through the square and church.
In the historic area. Very pretty church with a lot of history. Worth going to on a walking tour. Calm oasis in the city.

During my visit to Macau last month with my family,i had the priviledge to visit there.Although i didnt went inside,but it looks great from outside.Very old catholic church,but very well maintained.Its on the Historic city centre,so u wil find lots of people around u always.So
a Beautiful classic Catholic church. There is a museum there, but I did not have a chance to visit it.
The surroundings of the church are beautiful and the church is lovely. It doesn't look old outside but it was very well maintained, religious or not, this is pretty and worth the walk.

The church doesn't really look "old" from outside because the administrators are really maintaining this place. The architectural design and display inside however will tell how rich the history is. If you want to take good pictures, try to arrive early, like 7am, avoiding big
Be careful and make sure the taxi driver gives you a quote as ours drove the long way round. The church is beautiful but try and get there early to avoid the crowds.
Good enough as it's the oldest catholic church in CHINA. The restoration was done skillfully and it's really a gem from whether religiously or aesthetically point of view.
Amazing piece of history in Macau, great location for photography and local cuisine. Nothing to dislike.

St. Domingo's Church is a simple yet elegant historical landmark in the middle of Senado Square. It's a small church beautifully showcasing European architecture. The interior is very solemn and lovely as well. It 's very similar to many old churches in the Philippines. When in

Well photographed the exterior is reflective of Macau history and World Heritage. Take time to visit the religious museum upstairs and to sit in the church, reflect on the style/the décor and of course all who have passed this way. One of my lasting memories of Macau will be a
While you are in the Senado Square area you will run into this church. It's a beautiful example of Portuguese architecture inside & out.
This is a beautiful old European church. Could only look at the exterior as the inside is totally stripped out and being renovated.
A nice colonial church in the middle of the city. was in repair when i went there. I did not have the chance to see the church inside.
It was fine...if you visit to Ruin's of Paul's then plan visit together. It is under renovation so nothing much to see.
Something bout Macau besides the idea of Casinos and Hotels. European/Portuguese feeling mixed Asian shops on the side :). A walk from here can take you to St Paul's.
The church is not big but it's nice and quite! There is Saint Mary's statue on the 3rd floor.
I loved getting to see the Portuguese influence on the city.I wish I could have gone in, but it closes earlier.

WE traveled within Europe for a while, hence didn't find the church too much a new thing. However, it does have sense of European (Portuguese to be precise) feel... our baby visited church for the first time, very cute!
Maybe I am not biggest fan of churches. Yes, interesting to see it if you are in the area. It's part of walk in historical city.
The building is beautiful and the different nationalities and ethnies of people that gather and go there adds a especial sparkle.

My famiy is a catholic family, so when i take my parents to this area and they see this church they got excited. For some people the church is nothing special, but for us that come from a small town in Indonesia the church is more great from what we have in our town. My parents

TIP: anticipated Holy Mass : Saturdays 5:00 pm in Portuguese This Yellow colored Church is located at the center of Senado Square.
Many review make note that the church is nothing special, however I enjoyed the simple church as part of Macau's Portuguese history. Worth a look if wandering by.
church was nice, don't miss small museum in the back where you can watch few historical artefacts. Nicely renovated
Just a old church in the middle of a busy square. No taking pictures inside, so if you seen a Church before, u seen this. Check out the Square, more interesting.
It's clean, It's well-maintained, It's worth visiting. The church itself doesn't have anything extraordinary to attract tourist. It was the history it carries. An old building in a modern city.
Nice Catholic church that has mass schedules daily. A good landmark to meet up when in Macau. Near shopping streets.

This our second visit to Macau and on both occasions we had the pleasure of attending Mass at this beautiful church. The mass I assume was said in Portugese / Macanese? The layout of the Church and the statues etc, takes you back in time. Great experience!
This is a lovely church, located at the far end of Senado square. Its yellow façade with green windows is absolutely lovely and its interior does not disappoint, as well.
Really liked the church and it was easy to find do to everything being so well sign posted in Macau.
The church has museum at back side of the church on the 2nd floor and above. You should enter through an aisle at the right side of the church.
There are many churches situated throughout Macao, and this one is still functional, beautiful, and marvelously preserved. Definitely one to see, especially at Christmas and other religious holidays.
This is a place that i recommend tourist to visit! Is a beautiful and well kept Catholic building! I like to take photo, so have taken a lot of picture at here.
Beautiful Church. Well-preserved. A typical Catholic Church. It is very serene inside. Must drop by when you're in Senados Square.

It is just a beautiful Church! Close to Senator Place, colorful, quiet place, especially if outside crowded I feel attracted by historic churches. And this one is without doubt, with all its charm the most beautiful one in Macau.

Macau is full of nice churches and St Domingo's is worthy of a visit. It is a spacious and light church that is well maintained. Best to go early in the morning, as it gets very busy once the Chinese tour groups arrive from the mainland.
Very pretty church surrounded by shops!!!!! You can go inside and take photos. I felt guilty so made a donation

Everywhere else from Senado Square to the Ruins are bustling and crowded. The church practices silence in its premise and this is a wonderful way to get away from all that noise outside. In addition to that, I went when the weather was ridiculously hot. My face and arms were
Regrettably the church was locked, so we could only view the building externally. The rain didn't help, but the view & the church was beautiful
The museum was a great place to visit which is on the right side of the church. You will need a few minutes to see it all but it is worth while to see
A church is a church is a church. No difference, right? But when a church has some antiques that dates back a few hundred years, it is a must to visit, if you are interested in antiques
They are restoring the place so we couldn't go to the main church but there are displays upstairs. Worth a look and it's free.

A soulful person will be amazed and infused by the experience of visiting St. Domingo's Church. The amazing amount of history offered is almost over-whelming! Put this place on your list of things to see when you visit Macau.
Beautiful facade, I took photos, but it is closed for renovations, fascinating history of multiple ownership by different religious organisations.

This church is a very pleasant stop in the historic route. It's is definitely Portugese in style. Not the most ornate church you'll ever see but for being in China it is a bit surprising.

C1 ( 2013.06.19 ) There was a quiet and beautiful churches with Portuguese-style. The church is located at the entrance to Largo do Senado. In the church, there was museum having many exhibits. Portuguese-style exhibits associated with the Church was very interesting. With
it is a beautiful church and visitors must keep quiet in the church which made going in to sit on the pews a pleasant experience.
We visited twice, and felt disappointed, it felt more of a shopping are! People had no respect at all, noisy and took pictures without paying respecting other people who came to pray.

It was my birthday when we were visiting Macau, so it was a good opportunity to say a little prayer in this church. It's a quaint and cozy church, representative of Macau's history. Visitors can go in and photographs are allowed, even if you're not there to pray.
This is one of the most beautiful churches I have visited as its so perfectly preserved what a piece of history so gracefully preserved and I hope they preserve it for a 1,000 more years

It locates at senado sq., so it's really convenient to go. The church is not big but quite beautiful and good atmosphere. I bet most of travelers come to senado sq., so it's not bad to take a walk here.

This had to be one of the nicest churches I've seen before. A nice buttery yellow exterior paint with dark green on the shutters. The interior was very stunning and the statues and various religious elements around the sides were incredibly cool. When you walk to the right
Don't expect too much. Ordinary working church. A nice & quite getaway from the street noise. Say a prayer, enjoy the peace.
Just beautiful as we walked in when the choir were practising. Definitely worth having a look at if you are in the vicinity.

I hadn't done any real research before embarking on my day-out in Macau during my stopover in Hong Kong but this church was a pleasant surprise. Brightly coloured, simple yet it has something about it, at least for me. Probably having something Portuguese in the middle of Asia.

St. Dominic's Church is not far from Senado Square on a pedestrian street. It is a pale yellow typical Portuguese church, lovely from the outside. The interior is worth seeing but is extremely simple and humble.
you will really see this church because you will pass by here on your way to the Ruins of St. Paul Church. The exterior is very Portuguese design/influence.

I don't usually like to visit churches, but we were attracted to this church as we were strolling through the center of the old city of Macau. It is just so beautiful and inviting outside that we decided to go in. It is not a big church so it will take you but a few moments to
This is a beautiful church in the middle of the city. Dont forget to light a candle and offer a thanksging/petition when you visit.

old portuegese church. behind the church it's a museum which contains catholic artefact from ancient europe that brought to macau by misionary and portuegese ruler at that time, it's pretty interesting especially if you a history maniac.

Just pop in and sit quietly for a few minutes. This is a great retreat from the hustle and bustle of the streets nearby. During my visit I observed 2 Buddhist monks taking pictures of themselves inside!

visit it to click pics a decent spot, we also witnessed parade by kids.. in fancy dresses , it was amazing.. !

Just minutes away from Senado Square. Easily spotted as it would be the first church you'll see on the way. Quiet and tranquil inside, totally opposite when you step out the doors to the Square.The interior architecture of the church is just beautiful. Simple and humble version
Take 5 minutes to be aware of the historic information
One of the better museums around Hong Kong. Wasn't there when I first moved to Hong Kong, but tells a great story of Macau as you wander through.

One of the things you tick off on your list - been there, saw it, ticked my tourist list, and forgot about it. It is small, and pretty normal looking - nothing elaborate or grand about it. There are some cute shops around to pick up souvenirs - we picked up a Macau rooster - no,

Lots of history (probably) but you'll not know it unless you bring a guidebook. Still, inside is basic but beautiful, and it's a great place to duck into from the Square. The Square is loud & noisy, and inside St Domingo's it's quiet and calm. A nice contrast, and a beautiful

The exterior of this church is just beautiful. I love the style of the Senate Square part of town. The inside of the church is not on the same level as the exterior, and the artifacts could probably be skipped, but the church as a whole should definitely be on your list in
Am in love with Portuguese interior design style. So down to earth with pastel color. Nothing grand, but simply beautiful
Try to get there when they first open the church in the morning, I think around 10am. This is a beautiful church with a very nice religious art museum. It is perfectly maintained.
Old church reminds one of those churches in Europe, but nevertheless worth a look.

We really like St. Domingo's church near Senado Square. There is not much to see inside and it can appear underwhelming compared to Italian Catholic churches but its nice to see the more simple, humble version of a church built for Dominican worship. St. Domingo's is

google: A pretty church with a large museum at the back worth visiting.
Sadly, it was under renovation when we went, so we could only see the upstairs museum.  Still remarkable!  Gorgeous site.
Historical attraction. Worth to visit.

text.quote: Museum featuring race cars, motorbikes & memorabilia from the Macau Grand Prix & a race simulator.
trip: I really liked this museum. I came here alone and enjoyed looking at all the race cars they had. I found it very educational also
The GP muesum is closed!!! Walked all the way there from Senado square to find it closed even though the website still says its open!!! VERY DISAPPOINTING!!
The Grand Prix museum is closed for renovation ☹ Even the Wine museum is closed. In front of the museum there's a bus station heading to Senado Square. Ride bus #3
closed for renovation. went all the way here and found that the place is closed for renovation. should have provide alternative to enjoy the collection while they renovating the place

My wife & I went there yesterday, & was disappointed to find the place - together with the Wine Museum, all closed for renovation until further notice. There is a notice put up in front of the main entrance... Those planning to visit please take note !!
Had fun with the variety of information and the displays! Had a 3-day tour with my hubby & this museum was a quick and great place to relax after the busy walk at Macao’s metro.
When we go here, the museum is closed until dont know when. its a little bit dissapointing. no update information and it a little hard to go here from acros the road as we must go underway

My husband and I were super excited to visit the museum. We made sure to check the website, TripAdvisor and with the hotel to make sure it was open. We walked 30 minutes in torrential rain to find the building only to discover that it was closed for renovations and wouldn't be
This place is recommended by hotel staff which very near to hotel area. The place is under indoor. This place are give to people than like F1 because inside have a lot F1 old and new design if F1.

Amazing place with cars driven by Michael Schumacher, Ayrton Senna, etc. on display and one can really get close to these display cars. Place is relaxed and no crowd. Also, place allows one free ride on the driving simulator of the Macau Street Circuit. Can spend an hour or more
Grand Prix museum is very well maintained and has great collection of racing cars and bikes. Great place to visit for kids and racing enthusiast.
A must visit to understand the Macau Grand Prix circuit! Well kept with few great car selections. Do it along with the Wine Museum
I'm a race fan so I was like a kid in a candy store. There is also a wine museum with wine tasting in the same building so the daughters went wine tasting while I took my time in the F1 museum

visited last March 2017 one of the places in Macau that you can visit for free it was not that interesting if you are not into cars/vehicles/automobiles it's a great place because there are plenty of vehicles on display race cars, classic cars, motorcycles also the wine museum

I did not expect this place to be free. Very well-maintained, very informative and very nice displays of racing cars from different eras. If you are a racing enthusiast or have a penchant for racing cars, this is one place you should visit.

The museum is located in the basement of the tourism center. However, it contains many wonderful treasures inside, including the cars and bikes from many famous F1 drivers. A large exhibit discusses the history of the Macau Grand Prix and a second exhibit highlights Michael

i did not expect much for this. but, there are many good collections both motorcycles and cars. they also have many info about each model. if you like any motor sports, you could spend good time here.

Cool display of racing cars from various generations. They attempt to recreate the history of F1 in Macao and the place is well maintained. and free. There is also a wine museum adjacent to this. Good place for photographs for half hour to one hour.

The museum has quite a range of racing machines - cars and bikes - from various vintages. It is interesting to trace the progression from earlier days to the present. One of the exhibits is a car driven by Ayrton Senna. There is plenty of information on the Grand Prix circuit

My son is a bit of a petrol head so we went out of our way to make a visit. Although free the museum is quite small which makes it a very short visit. There is a wine museum opposite so you can combine the two.

I was expecting very little for free, and I was right. However, it was still nice to see, as I have watched the Macau Grand Prix in the past and many F1 World Champions won at Macau. Unfortunately, as a Formula 1 fan, this stuff was based around the Formula 3 series, meaning I

Great seeing those racing cars, but reading the history was quite snooze-worthy, I think it's better if they had LED TVs to show how the racers were when they were driving or film snippets of their own victories, but they also had the racing game which you'd need a ticket for
Ayrton Senna? Yes! And also the other racers, they started their career in Macau. And this place collected almost all the things that they used before. Highly recommend for all the F1 lovers!

This is just a crackin' little petrol head heaven. There was even Bikes from my home town on show!! Road racers from Northern Ireland. They have Trophy cases with Trophies from 80 yrs ago as well as F1 suits!! There is a little Simulator as well. Some great Ayrton Senna
after a long walk we found the museum, it is nice and I guess the hobby of a car fan. if you like f3 it is ok, the only good thing it is free.

If you're into motor racing this is worth visiting. There's no entrance fee and there are some good displays including Ayrton Senna, Michael Schumacher and David Coulthard's old cars. The museum is about the Macau Grand Prix. There are also some bikes and older cars on display

It's a free museum, more than what I expected to see. Have many racing car display and history......one thing is that there was almost one security per display -_-" So watch out, do not attempt to do anything to the racing car~~Lol~!! Spend 30-45 minutes. FYI, there is a wine

Free entry, short walk away from the Ferry Terminal or Fishermans wharf, The museum itself is tiny takes 15 minutes to see everything, You could take longer if you want to look at every vehicle in detail, the gaming platform was closed to my disappointment and looks to be
Nice racing museum , old F1 race cars , good,place for racing enthusiasts , perfect place to relive old racing days

This place boasts of a rare collection of race bikes like Ducati and F1 cars. This is located near the wine museum and is hard to miss. The entry is free for visitors. Make sure you check out this place during your stint at Macau. P:S The museum closes at 18:00. Plan
My husband loves F1 so this was a must see for him, it did nothing for me as Im not into racing but he loved seeing the cars and reading the history of the sport, cars and drivers.

Well firstley I must say that you will be done in 20-30 mins. So if you are waiting for the boat this could be a thing to do. You can look at some cars and that is about it. The simulator is not worth waiting for.
Great venue if you are in Motorsports and good place for a hot/cold day exercise with a boy. Interesting to see the history of racing in Macau
Great walk through the history of Formula 1. Lots of cars from different eras to look at. Information and a history lesson all in 1.
Lots of classics on display, worth to visit when in Macau. Not too easy to find but worth the time. Good

I knew I needed to visit this museum when I was in Macau, and was not disappointed. It's a small and well-kept space, with about a dozen cars (mostly Formula 3) and a half-dozen motorcycles. An interesting and lighted diorama shows the still-in-use street course that snakes

This museum is in the same building as the Wine Museum and both are free. It's just opposite the bauhinia square (8 minutes walk from the ferry terminal). It tells you how the grand prix of Macau was set up and there are many cars (and also some motos) to see.

Macao is known as the Asia’s Las Vegas, besides gambling. There is also an international event, Grand Prix, which is a challenging and popular program because the road race in Macau is very narrow and gets many bends. Racers from different parts of the world will gather together

I went there once when I was small, but I have never forgotten the memories about visiting there. It was fun and everything was new to me. Recently, I went there once, again, with my friend. It introduces the history of Grand Prix of Macau, it also introduced numbers of

The Grand Prix Museum is a motor racing museum in Sé, Macau, China. It is co-located with and adjacent to the Macau Wine Museum. The museum was inaugurated at the 40th Macau Grand Prix on 18 November 1993. The museum exhibits are provided by different government departments and

The Macau Grand Prix is the largest international event in Macau, it has been held over sixty-third year. If you are a racing fan, I highly recommend to visit the Macau Grand Prix Museum. It is worth it, but pay attention to the number of tourists on holiday. Macao's runway is

I visited the Macau Racing Museum and held a racing race in Macau for a long time. The museum recorded different periods of racing, very old racing cars and modern cars. Their appearance was very different. Racing simulator, very interesting. I think this place is very
Nice collection . A must visit for Grand Prix Fan. No entry charges, free for everyone. The staff/ guards are very polite & cooperative.

Excellent exhibit of the historic and present time facts of Macau Formula 3 Grand Prix., with many real cars that participated in the events throughout the years. I believe it will close some time for renovations and upgrades soon. It is well worth it.

If you have been to the Ferrari World in Abu Dhabi, this museum is just an average. Even the racing game is a video game model. It shares the same building with the Wine Museum. Many tourists purchase the Portugal wines there.

Thought the museum could do with a bit of updating I found it very interesting, and very good given its free to enter. I was surprised at how many of the great F1 drivers had raced in Macau and it is well laid out. If you enjoy motor sports this is well worth a visit
located in the same place like wine muse. U can see many collection of f1 car and nice to take a photo
We stay 2 hrs there. Many good race cars there. There is a small place to test driving with big screen. Motorcycles are cool ,too.

When this was initially opened, I imagine it could have been quite exciting. As the years have passed, the exhibits have stayed the same and it's not a must see for the casual enthusiast. Just keep in mind It focuses on the Macau Grand Prix, not globally. Hey, it's
A well set out out museum photos are permitted. Excellent balance between visual and written history. Majority of displays for Formula 3.

Our son insisted we should get inside here before anything else. He was not disappointed because he could sample sitting on some of the race cars! What really struck me were photos of our well-known car-racing champion, Mr. Laurel. Just looking at his photos along with the likes

" On the path"for a touristic visit; Even if I've no special interest about F1, this free of charge museum gave me plenty of interesting spots !! Even more, it's next door with the wine museum . Interesting discovering.

Those interested in speed should make time to visit this museum. The best thing is that entry is free. The Macau grand Prix is also hosted nearby and makes for an interesting look around. Models of cars, etc are neatly placed which makes them eye catching.
a Free Museum with wide array of different car models and history of Grand Prix and their owners/drivers

The Grand Prix museum is located in the Centros de Actividades Turisticas which is opposite Golden Lotus Square and Fisherman's Wharf. There is no entrance fee, but you can buy a ticket for the racing simulation ride, which is perhaps the only interactive activity that they have

Adjacent to the Wine museum, the Macau Grand Prix museum is free for entry. The museum shows lots of different types of race cars in different decades. It also introduces the Guia circuit about their straight street and tight corners. There tourists can try playing a Car
The museums is free for entry, good to stop by for motoring enthusiasts. Small museum but many life size models of famous racing cars. Short walk away from the Sands hotel.
I like F1 so I enjoyed looking at the old cars. If you are into racing this is one of the places you have to visit in Macao.

The Grand Prix Museum showcases a whole range of race cars and some motorbikes right from the beginning to the latest. There's also a podium there if you want to take some pics posing as winners. Everybody will enjoy the scenery watching all the luxury of cars all over the world

Museu do Grande Prémio (Grand Prix Museum) displays plenty of F3 and F1 racing vehicles and motorbike from legendary drivers and winner of Grand Prix motor racing. Besides, a lots of related information is displayed such as the racing suits, trophy and biography of legendary
Macau has a Grand Prix Racing ,this place collect memories from the past of Formula racing sport to speed or car's lover

Being a Car racing enthusiast, it was a wonderful experience. The Grand Prix Museum showcases a whole range of race cars and some motorbikes right from the beginning to the latest. There's also a podium there if you want to take some pics posing as winners. ;)
all car raisers can come here for fun. everybody will enjoy the scenery watching all the luxury of cars all over the world and even the vintage cars that has been used to the grand prix

Outstanding automotive and motorcycle museum, lots of cars (Formula 3 and sedans) and motorcycles. Great displays, photos, videos of races at Macau GP. Highly recommend this if you love racing or just love cars or bikes. Was free when we went but I believe they are going to star

This museum is a must even if you are not a motor racing fan. It has old to new formula 1 cars rally cars and super bikes. Entry was free! And you can get really close to see the mechanics and styles of the cars. It's quite small so can finish in 30 minutes. I recommend
Brilliant place loved it lots to see lots of mega things to see about macau gp really worth seeing very interesting place

It's free so we've just hop in! Not really tourist attraction as we're the only guest when we arrive. Great collection though, especially the car the Schumacher actually drives! Also the Filipino racer (Arsenio Laurel) car is there. I'm not aware that there is a Filipino 2 -time
For any motor enthusiast this is well worth a visit, from a model T ford to racing cars and bikes. There is also a racing simulator which is free to use after getting ticket from front desk.

Located close to the Ferry terminal and the Rio Hotel, with free entrance. Spotlessly clean and shiny show place, with beautiful racing cars, monocycles, and small carting vehicles. There are exhibits of the Grand Prix history at Macau, and 2 race driving simulators for kids and

The Grand Prix museum has host of old racing cars to the new models. There is no entry fee. Also you get one chance at the racing simulator game per person. For that you need to collect a token from the entrance. Must see if you are a racing buff.
The museum is within walking distance from the ferry terminal, and admission is free. I wouldn't recommend going out of your way just to visit this museum, unless you are a huge motorsport fan.

text.wiki:
The Holy House of Mercy of Macau (Portuguese: Santa Casa da Misericórdia; Chinese: 仁慈堂大樓), is a historic building in Senado Square, Macau, China. Established as a branch of the Santa Casa da Misericórdia, it was first built in 1569 on the orders of the Bishop of Macau, Belchior Carneiro Leitão.
It was a medical clinic and several other social welfare structures in early Macau. It later served as an orphanage and refuge for widows of sailors lost at sea.
It is part of the Historic Centre of Macau, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

text.wiki:
São Lázaro  is the smallest civil parish (Portuguese: freguesia) of Macau, located in the central-east region of the Macau Peninsula. It is surrounded by the parishes of Nossa Senhora de Fátima, Santo António, and Sé. 
This parish was one of five in the former Municipality of Macau, one of Macau's two municipalities that were abolished on 31 December 2001 by Law No. 17/2001, following the 1999 transfer of sovereignty over Macau from Portugal to China. While their administrative functions have since been removed, these parishes are still retained nominally.
One-third of its region is covered by Guia Hill (Portuguese: Colina da Guia, Chinese: 松山 or 東望洋山). 3% of factories in Macau are located in the district.


== Education ==
Tertiary education:

United Nations University Institute on Computing and Society


=== Primary and secondary schools ===
Public schools:

Macao Conservatory - Headquarters and school of MusicThe school of music is designated as a public secondary school programme. It is located in this parish.
Escola Secundária Luso-Chinesa de Luís Gonzaga Gomes
Escola Primária Oficial Luso-Chinesa "Sir Robert Ho Tung" (何東中葡小學) - Preschool, primary school, and special education
Escola Primária Luso-Chinesa da Flora (二龍喉中葡小學)Private tuition-free schools:

Chan Sui Ki Perpetual Help College - Primary and secondary school
Yuet Wah College - Preschool through secondary school
Escola Kai Chi (啟智學校) - Special educationPrivate non-free schools:

Pui Ching Middle School - Preschool through secondary school
Jardim de Infância "D. José da Costa Nunes" (魯彌士主教幼稚園) - Preschool


=== Public library ===

The parish is home to Macao Central Library, the main library of the Macao Public Library system.


== Healthcare ==
The Macau government operates the Centro de Saúde Macau Oriental (塔石衛生中心) in Tap Seac.

trip: Flora Garden is a large public park and garden located just off of Avenida de Sidónio Pais on the Macau Peninsula. I like visiting here during Chinese New Year when the weather is cooler and the garden is decorated with cherry blossoms and other seasonal plants and flowers.

text.wiki:
The Macao Science Center also known as Macau Science Center (MSC; Chinese: 澳門科學館; Portuguese: Centro de Ciência de Macau) is a science center in Sé, Macau, China. 
The main building has a distinctive, asymmetrical, conical shape with a spiral walkway and a large atrium inside. Galleries lead off the walkway, mainly consisting of interactive exhibits aimed at science education.
There is also a planetarium with 3D projection facilities and Omnimax films.
The building is in a prominent position by the sea and is now a landmark of Macau. It is visible when arriving on the ferry from Hong Kong.


== History ==
The project to build the science center was conceived in 2001 and completed in 2009. The building was designed by Pei Partnership Architects in association with I. M. Pei and construction started in 2006. The structural engineer was Leslie E. Robertson Associates. The center was opened in December 2009 by Chinese President and General Secretary of the Communist Party Hu Jintao.It caught on fire on 20 November 2015, due to welding occurring on the top level of the building.


== Gallery ==

		
		


== See also ==

List of museums in Macau
